column8: An Unforgettable Wildlife Experience in Minneriya
column11: Minneriya National Park is one of the best places in Sri Lanka to see wild elephants in their natural habitat. The safari drive takes you through forests, grasslands, and around the famous Minneriya tank. During the dry season, you can witness large herds gathering, which is truly impressive. Besides elephants, we also spotted deer, birds, and other wildlife. The experience feels peaceful and exciting at the same time. A must-visit park for nature lovers and photographers
It was great to see elephants in a national park but we actually saw more on the road Cannot believe they have elephants walking amongst the traffic in Sri Lanka

The park is very beautiful and it is easy to see the elephants; however, it is definitely crowded and jeeps are sometimes queued when an animal is spotted (by the way, the same is annoyed). A limited number and better organisation would be highly desirable.

Minneriya National Park, located in Sri Lanka‚Äôs North Central Province, is a renowned wildlife sanctuary famous for its large herds of wild elephants. The park covers about 8,900 hectares and centers around the ancient Minneriya Tank

Great visit and one we had looked forward to for a long time.  The experience did not disappoint ........ large herd of elephants (all ages) close up and individual males in our tour further into the park. Yes, it is busy but if you have the right driver you will get a most enjoyable visit and see these wonderful mammals in their natural habitat.
I see more asian eliphant baby eliphant and best experience in sri lanka i see monkeys,peakok,tuskar,little birds and egal
A once in a lifetime experience these a wild elephants and the are amazing in their natural element!!  Don't miss out on this park in August and Sept all the elephants come here these months.

column8: Minneriya provides an authentic elephant watching experience
column11: This was an excursion my family and I were really excited about. We were met by our safari driver at our hotel and taken to the park. There are lots of local independent tour operators in the area who are able to do the drives in the park. We had a driver throughout our trip in Sri Lanka and he organised the jeep safari on our behalf. Our jeep driver spoke good English. He encouraged us to stand up as he drove through the park. And it felt exhilarating to drive along dusty tracks, hair whipping in your face, sun shining and excitedly looking out for wildlife. The park had a 'jurassic park' type vive about it.... ....And then we came across monkeys to whet our appetite. Before coming upon a small herd of elephants. There was a female, very, very heavily pregnant- who was likely to give birth in the next week or so. Another female had a baby calf (about 1-2weeks old). The elephants can come VERY close to the jeeps. When there's an elephant siting, a LOT of jeeps descend. And at times, I felt a bit uncomfortable at the number of carfuls of people. However, if the elephants do approach, the jeep drivers do make a hasty retreat. Everywhere you go in Sri Lanka, there is litter everywhere. It was a nice change that there was hardly any plastic waste in the park where the elephants roam.... .....Apart from one area around the other side of the lake. Tourists are encouraged to get out of the jeep, pose for photos at the waterside, and climb a lookout view point. There was SO MUCH rubbish littered here. As about 100 people were congregated, a shout went out from our driver. A herd of elephants were approaching. Within minutes we were all ushered back into our jeeps. We thought this was for safery, but this was actually so that we could follow them again and watch them enter the water for a refreshing dip. We saw baby elephants, pregnant matriarchs, bull elephants, a few juveniles play-fighting. And we learnt how elephants kick up the grass and loosen it from the ground, pick it up with their trunks and shake out the grass before eating it. They truly are magnificent animals and it was lovely to see them in a natural habitat, where human interaction is limited to about 30-ish jeep-fuls at a time. All in all we saw about 30-ish elephants during our afternoon safari. And a bonus: on our way back to our hotel, we saw elephants in the grass beside the roadside!!

This is best national park.very beautiful and we saw many elephants and some other animals.our tour organized by "wild paradise safari minneriya & kaudulla" company in sigiriya.they have very  comfortable jeeps.highly recommend!
You see a lot of elephants and monkeys. It is a beautiful park and a half day is more than sufficient. Only buying tickets is quite chaotic.

What nature! Wild elephants, eagles, monkeys, and more. The only pity is the number of jeeps driving around... a bit double since we were part of this circus ourselves. But a safari can and should be done with more respect for the animals. There were so many that 1 elephant could not cross the road to its herd. Not ok and dangerous

This place is appalling and to be avoided unless you want to be disappointed. We drove 45 minutes through a bumpy track in a jeep to sit in a queue of about 200 jeeps to see maybe 10 elephants. The whole experience was dreadful and underwhelming.

Ultimate disappointment. As someone that visited all wildlife parks in Tanzania with great guides, I must say that this experience was terrible. The driver did not really explain anything to us, no wildlife to view other than few bird species (the driver did not even know what species of birds we were viewing), a monkey, a baby croc and few elephants. Supposedly the safari would last 3 hours but he drove us back after 1 hour max. The driver and entrance fees are a total rip-off. AVOID!!
Amazing and wonderful safari in Minneriya. I saw many elephants there and park entrance is bit high.but anyway I loved to be there. Thanks
Too many jeeps. We only breathe exhaust gases. We got caught in traffic jams because all the jeeps are happening on word and go to the same place.

We organised a jeep safari through our hotel and really enjoyed it. We started at 6am and were advised that this was a better time as it is less crowded. We saw three groups of elephants and saw 50 animals in total. We also saw foxes, monkeys and a range of birds. And expensive entry fee of 22k rupees for 2 people‚Ä¶

Wow! The landscapes are absolutely stunning here and it‚Äôs lovely to see the natural environment has not been exploited. We were very lucky to see over 60 elephants in our early morning jeep safari. Our guide informed us it‚Äôs been quiet lately and not many elephants around so we were very pleased. The man was very informative and respectful of the animals, which was great to see. I did not get his name but he is based in the Polonnaruwa area (+94 779443105 or +94 776965134). Saw other animals too including monkeys and jackals. Lots of birds such as heron, pelicans, peacocks and fowl. When we first arrived at the national park at 6am we had a warm welcome, the toilets were impeccable and cleaned regularly. Well worth the visit and early morning wake up!!!
Beautiful nature and beautiful elephants. I feel like way too many jeeps. I regret being in one of those jeeps.

Overall ‚Ä¶ disappointing. We visited Yala NP and had an amazing time. Minneriya is over priced, overcrowded and far too commercialised. 40 mins to get the ticket, 30 mins to queue to get in and 30 mins to the lake where we met with a Jeep Bun Fight. At least 50 Jeeps around the elephant herd. Which was great. But go to Yala. Go elsewhere
Saw a range of animals and loads of elephants including plenty of babies. The jeep ride was so much fun. Very good value for money.

The nature of the park is beautiful, we have seen many elephants, buffalo, jackals, black langue monkey, many birds. The cost is a thief, 30‚Ç¨! Bad organization: 1 h wait to make ticket (and we are in low season!), Another queue to enter (in 4 to write by hand the license plate of the vehicles on a book and by hand), overcrowding of jeeps around the annoyed elephants (can not do a closed number???)

This place is chaotic‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs like a backpackers paradise with way too many cars‚Ä¶ elephant sightings are great but not at all private or sympathetic to the fact it‚Äôs a national park not a zoo‚Ä¶
Nothing much - lots of elephants; we didn‚Äôt see any other animals.  Yala National park was much more interesting.  The safari was pretty short as there was nothing much.

This is a great park (small for a park) for seeing elephants although it becomes reckless with so many tour guides and jeeps all rushing in to corner an elephant and its off spring, but that is what a safari is about. The roads are very bouncy and you do get thrown around when standing but that is a personal choice to stand or sit. We saw many elephant herds, peacocks, birds Quite early on we came into contact with various groups of elephants. It is a beautiful park with some rocks and a viewpoint on top of a plateau where you can walk to without threat from wildlife. While the safari is hectic, its lovely to sit and watch the elephants and their babies, unfazed by all the star attractions about them. Highly recommended tour, we were there for hours.

Perhaps not the best national park but there are many elephants here.   Much like the other national parks this place is over populated by ute/jeeps with passenger cages on the back, and they race around trying to spot elephants.  It's madness, and you'll feel sorry for the elephant in the end, after all, all they are trying to do is have a life, and they are pestered by diesel fume chugging ute/jeeps all day long. The roadways are in very poor repair so you'll be bounced and bumped around like you never thought possible

This park worths the visit and has lots of elephants roaming freely. We enjoyed it, especually our toddler who was facinated by the nature and the animals. Better check the weather before visiting and book last minute in order to avoid heavy rain.

In this park we had to deal with jeeps that we could stand in that immediately gives a different perspective. Quite early on we came into contact with various groups of elephants. It is a beautiful park with some rocks and a viewpoint on top of a plateau where you can walk to without threat from wildlife.

Just terrible! As soon as an elephant is seen, about 50 jeeps drive to this point and circle this one elephant and follow it. It's like a hunt and it really shocked me. If this is Safari then NO THANK YOU!!!

We went on a 4 hour safari,  starting at 7am.  We saw so many elephants close up. At the start,  there were more jeeps than elephants as drivers message each other when there is a sighting. But by doing a longer trip,  we got further into the park and there were far fewer tourists.
Great time lots of elephants a little bumpy but good fun . Guide very good wear lots of sun screen and take water and camera

Incredible experience. We already did a safari in Tanzania but regarding elephants that was an amazing experience, we stayed super close to a family while they were eating. Full of elephants and i really recommend

It is great to see the elephants in this National Park. We had good guide and we very appreciated him getting us so close to the elephants. The less positive aspect of this tour is that there are too many vehicles and guides operating in the park.  At one point on our tour there were 12 vehicles around a small group of elephants.  It was not an experience connected you with nature.  I would struggle to recommend it. On a wider point, many of the 5 star reviews for the park are posted by Sri Lankan tour operators who, presumably, provide services connected to the park.  That really undermines the credibility of TripAdvisor.

Elephants... we didn't need to get into the park to see them. Along the way from Polonnaruwa to Sigirya with scooters we saw some from afar, then one just down the road (we could have locked it up!) and in Sigirya, in the evening they turned them away from the accommodation facilities.

The park covers a wide area and we found the elephants at the furthest point on the safari! (45 minutes from the start.) The elephants seem familiar with the jeeps so they do get close and give you a good photo opportunity. While we did not see any, wild elephants are prevalent in the local area so a safari may not be needed :)
Exceptional place to see big heads of elephants . Beautiful forest reserve with a big tank you will never miss elephants .

The primary attraction of Minneriya is the large herds of elephants, especially during the "Elephant Gathering". This occurs from July to October when hundreds of elephants congregate around the park‚Äôs central reservoir The park's landscape, with its grasslands, water reservoirs, and lush forested areas, adds to the overall safari experience. Visitors often note the peacefulness and natural beauty of the surroundings.

Natural park famous especially for the presence of elephants, which crowd the park during the dry season. This presence, I was told, is due to the lake retreating in the warm season, and allows the formation of a wide expanse of fresh grass, which becomes a delicious food for elephants. Entry allowed only with jeeps with drivers. There is a large crowd in the late afternoon, when the animals come out of the forest to go eat near the lake. I visited it immediately in the early afternoon, Recommendation as there is no traffic of other jeeps I almost had the feeling of going on a private tour. The thrill of finding yourself with elephants walking in their natural habitat was unforgettable.

It is really worth a visit!! It's exciting and we saw a hundred elephants, even very closely, families with young, adults alone,fantastico.Il all in a wonderful landscape.In this period hundreds of elephants gather because the lakes drop in level leaving uncovered fresh grass excellent for them. We organized at the last moment our safari, from there to 2 hours later.Passing in front of the main entrance of the park (on the road between Minnerya and Sigirya), we spoke with one of the various guides near the parked jeeps and negotiated a total price of 45000 LKR, about 135 euros, including entry, jeep and Guide for 3 persone.Abbiamo a jeep just for us and the driver also made us make different routes to detach from other jeeps.Duration 3 hours,bring water, lots of sun, but unforgettable experience
We took a jeep tour through the park, stopping for looking at the animals such as elephants. Amazing for photo opportunities.

What an experience this place is, we've never seen so many elephants in one place! They are treated with such deserved deference by the many jeeps watching them, such wonderful creatures and in such close proximity.
Beautiful images of elephant families and families, on the green grass, playing young, bragging males... Maybe too many 4x4s, with their noisy engines and fumes. It's worth it if you like elephants.

Visiting Minneriya National Park was a highlight of my trip to Sri Lanka. The park is famous for its impressive ‚ÄúGathering‚Äù of wild elephants, and seeing hundreds of these magnificent animals converging around the waterholes during the dry season was absolutely breathtaking. The park‚Äôs diverse landscapes, from lush grasslands to dense forests, provide a great backdrop for wildlife spotting. Besides elephants, I encountered a variety of birds and other animals, each safari drive offering new surprises. The peaceful environment and natural beauty made for a truly relaxing experience. I also appreciated the historical significance of the park, with its ancient irrigation systems hinting at Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich cultural heritage. For the best experience, I‚Äôd recommend visiting during the peak gathering season and going with a knowledgeable guide to get the most out of your visit.

So many elephants / so much nature / too many Jeeps! Interesting safari - you can see many elephants up close but there are perhaps too many jeeps crossing this park at once - with noise and pollution - perhaps the entrance should be calmed down - even if tourism is a primary source of livelihood here

As a tour guide at Minneriya National Park, I am constantly amazed by the park‚Äôs remarkable wildlife and stunning landscapes. Known for its incredible elephant gatherings, Minneriya offers a unique and awe-inspiring safari experience. Visitors have the opportunity to witness these majestic creatures in their natural habitat, especially during the dry season when the park‚Äôs large reservoir attracts hundreds of elephants. Beyond the elephants, the park is home to diverse flora and fauna, including various bird species and endemic wildlife. Our goal is to provide an informative and immersive experience, ensuring that each guest leaves with a deep appreciation for Sri Lanka‚Äôs natural beauty. Whether you're a wildlife enthusiast or simply looking to connect with nature, Minneriya National Park is a must-visit destination that promises unforgettable moments. #ExploreSriLanka#ScenicLankaPersonalTourDrivers

This is among the world's best locations to see wild elephants. The visitor's vehicle park is next to the Habarana - Polonnaruwa main road. A huge visitors' vehicle parking area is available. There is a ticket booth where you must purchase a ticket in addition to making arrangements for a safari vehicle. It takes close to three hours to finish this entire journey.

Horrible: 300 animals for 500 jeep, this park is animal slavery, horrible Guide, even yelling at him, he goes on and he traces, I hate people who go as fast as possible to make as much money! We see that they are for the conservation of elephants and the planet: Tons of CO2, lots of people, I really pity the poor elephants who are being abused. I don't understand people's positive reviews. The number of jeep should be limited to protect animals. The Award: 40 ‚Ç¨ to see 10 elephants without stopping is inhuman! For 8 people, paying 85 000 lkr (~ 200 ‚Ç¨), (jeeps included), is horrible. Please stop feeding this business and this animal slavery, don't come to this horrible park. I hope you understand that This park is pure animal slavery and a money box!
You can see the Elephants very close by and good time to visit National park between June to November . Then you see elephants gathering.
Not to be missed, we saw a hundred elephants, breathtaking landscapes. Many jeeps were present, but the traffic was not excessive.

It was a very special experience and really worth it! It is best to book the safari directly from the side of the park and choose the afternoon tour as the period, as at this time the elephants come to the lakes/waterholes to refresh themselves and drink. Our guide Nadeesha explained a lot, answered all our questions to complete satisfaction and used the time in the park until the last minute - really great!

The best jeep safari I‚Äôve ever been on. Seeing the elephants in the wild was something special. Do‚Äôs - Find an honest Sri Lankan who can help you with cost. Our Uber driver has helped us. Instead of paying 40 000 SLR offered by our hotel staff. We paid 9 000 SLR to the jeep driver who picked us up at 6am and returned us at 9:45am - Entrance fee to the park at 22 000 SLR for my wife and I Don‚Äôt - Pay 40 000 or more SLR with hotel Give it a go. I‚Äôll never forget our experience today 28/07/2024

Nice afternoon trip. Take a jeep into the nature park and watch elephants. In addition to elephants, we also saw several species of eagles, waterfowl, a water buffalo and a water monitor. Beautiful park, you are sometimes stuck in traffic around a herd of eating elephants, because of course you are not the only one who comes to spot elephants. Still a special experience to get so close to wild elephants.

We had an amazing evening in the Minneriya National Park and saw huge herds of elephants, the youngest being only 6 days old! The jeeps were comfortable and we all felt very safe. Such a beautiful place

First off - a disclaimer. The national park is beautiful. But we went on a Jeep Safari with some company who's name I forget. And yes, we saw some elephants. There's something magical about seeing a family of elephants in the wild, munching on grass and seemingly at peace with the world. But then you zoom out and realise that you're sitting in one of about 20 jeeps, all crowded round the animals, trying to get closer while belching out thick diesel exhaust fumes. It was like being on the M25 at rush hour, just with a few elephants nearby. As I took part in this sorry scene, I felt a deep sense of shame and regret. Yes, I was a tourist and yes I was contributing to this. If you can live with that, then fine. For me, it's my last 'safari' - I'll watch the elephants on David Attenborough next time.
A safari trip in Minneriya National Park gave the opportunity to see not only elephants but also various wild animals in their natural habitat.
This was a great national park. We have seen a lot of elephants, also from very close! The safari drivers do really respect the animals.

Jeep drivers do not respect elephants. As soon as a small group is seen, around fifteen jeeps crowd around the elephants, breaking their peace. We could see baby elephants frightened by the noise of the engines. The elephants are literally surrounded by jeeps. It's very disturbing. In addition, the jeeps follow each other in line and you breathe exhaust gases for 3 hours. In addition, you will not see other animals, surely frightened by the noise and the smell of gasoline. Far from responsible tourism.
Well executed Jeep safari. Jeep and driver 4h tour for two adults in private 25k local money. Birds and elephants can be seen. It was a bit of a struggle at times, but it was worth it.

An absolute mesmerizing! Our visit to Minneriya National Park in Habarana was beyond extraordinary. Thanks to our expert safari driver, we had the privilege of encountering over 100 elephants in their natural habitat. From observing their daily routines to witnessing their playful antics, every moment was enchanting. Our kids were over the moon seeing so many elephants for the first time. This half-day adventure from Sigiriya is an absolute steal ‚Äì unbeatable value for an unforgettable experience

We had an excellent Safari with a young driver who knew the park and tried to find quieter spaces. I understand comments about the Grand Prix approach to the start of the Safari with so many vehicles but it‚Äôs a lovely park and one to enjoy. We saw dozens of elephants in several herds, including baby elephants, and the bird life was excellent too.
Really enjoy 4 hours safari. Amazing national park where the animals are free to roam. Plenty of elephants and different birds. Visit and enjoy with your kids

This is a stunning place with a lot of elephants on site. We saw 15 elephants during the half day morning trip (unsure on the name of our company) but this is a beautiful place and we were advised not to visit as we were already booked to visit Yala but if you can afford to do both i would recommend it as the elephant encounters we experienced (i know this is not the same for everyone) was worth every penny. We and a number of our vehicles did get stuck due to the ground conditions.

You are guaranteed to see elephants ! But do you want to see elephants almost being boxed in by so many jeeps all fighting to get the best spot for their visitors ! A guaranteed good tip for the drivers. The system needs to change . Timed  entries might work to reduce the amount of jeeps at one sighting. The early sighting as you entered the park was the most crowded. I actually wanted to move on not hear a baby elephant calling for its mother as it had been separated by jeeps! Boy those elephants are patient. Further in when the jeeps split off it was a little better. Sri Lankan National Parks, protect your elephants  if you want more tourists to visit. I for one felt really uncomfortable and had I realised how crowed the elephants would be I would  never have taken the trip! Please please , time your entries, American parks are now doing that and they are so much better for both the wildlife and the tourist. Your drivers are lovely and trying to earn a crust . I understand that but this practice is off putting. I would not recommend this until things change.

If you want to see wild elephants, then this is the place. We saw over 70, and you would have to be very unlucky not to see any. However, we also had mixed feelings. We had a brilliant driver who kept a distance from the elephants and parked up in areas where he thought they would come our way, which they mostly did. Some of the elephants came very close to our jeep which was amazing. Other drivers were much less considerate and drove up to the animals. Some drive guidelines/training/regulation would be helpful to ensure animal welfare isn't compromised.

We hired an open jeep and driver for a 3 hour tour through the park. Although the description of the park said there were lots of different types of animals we only saw elephants - which was an amazing experience! The day we went there were many jeeps. Unfortunately this meant that there was a frenzy to get close to the elephants and at one stage an elephant was clearly distressed at being cornered by the jeeps. Our driver was good and tried to tell other drivers to make a path for the elephants to cross but many drivers just wanted to get as close as possible. There was no sign of any regulation by park rangers - this is desperately needed.
We saw a lot of elephants there, and of course birds and a few other animal species. It was fun anyway

The rainy season begins at the end of October, but you can still see animals in the park. True, after African safaris everything is quite modest, but where else can you see Asian elephants and buffalos in the wild?)

This was very nice as the elephants were very close up and we had to wait until they decided to go. The park took a long time to go in and we only saw elephants by the lake and not much else but so many of them. It was not cheap about $US-00 and with all the jeeps there they made a lot of money that day!. The park only was designated in 1997 and before that was a wildlife sanctuary since 1938

I think 3 stars is enough.....Herds of elephants,,,,, where are those herds of elephants???????? Let's be a little serious when writing comments, because the only thing we do is deceive future tourists who want to come, based on the opinions they have seen,,, Elephants there are sisisisisi.... but don't expect to see herds, , because there aren't any, what you will see are herds of all-terrain cars, the place is nice sisissi....it's worth paying for what you see,,, in my opinion no,,, , Here I publish some photos of those herds of elephants,,,

Spent hours in queue for tickets, can get extremely crowded. Safari drivers have little to no respect for both animals and tourists alike. As a wildlife photographer myself, I was very disappointed in how the drivers behaved. Overall, park management is poor, too many vehicles gather in the same area as opposed to other national parks in the country.

Booked onto this safari as an extra one as it was recommended....it didn't disappoint. Loads of elephants here you are pretty much guaranteed to see something. Whether it's large herds, small families or single males they are massive, beautiful animals to take loads of pictures of from the open topped jeep.
Good Activity, 100% can see elephants. There are two sessions, morning or evening. We went for morning. The earlier the better if in the morning.

We had a private jeep safari tour organised by our accommodation (Sigiri rock home stay). It‚Äôs a 30 min drive from sigiriya Our guide picked us up from our accommodation and pointed out various wildlife including chameleons, cobras, eagles, water buffalos and peacocks. The main event was the numerous elephants scattered all over the park in herds of varying size. We saw at least 100 elephants including baby elephants (some days old). They wander around and sometimes come quite close. A memorable trip. At times, it felt like there were a lot of jeeps in the park, which was the only downside - but we were also one of them so can‚Äôt complain too much.

We set off in jeeps to hopefully see the elusive leopard in the park.  We did see one high up on a rock way off in the distance.  and saw lots of elephants close up which was great, buffalo and many bird life.  Great tour.

Visited in a private safari Jeep and collected our guide at the gate. He was excellent and had a great knowledge of the birds as well as excellent spotting ability and he pointed out many species we would have missed without his assistance. We spent four hours in the park and sited 42 species so an excellent result.
Enjoyed my jeep trip around this park. Saw lots of animals and birds. I was taken to a lot areas and felt I saw the park to its full advantage

We were taken to our jeep and driven to the park,,,we drove about a bit and saw some elephants but they were quite far from us and couldn‚Äôt really take any photos but our driver was very good and carried on driving about and it was worth it as we came across about 10 elephants it was an amazing sight... There was even a little baby one hiding by his mother. This was the highlight of our holiday we loved it so if your in the area you have to go!!!

We have been on many safaris, albeit in Africa, and this is the first time we felt uncomfortable viewing wild animals.  The park is small and has limited wildlife (we saw 2 small herds of elephants, a peacock, one empty eagle nest and a wasp nest). On the day of our visit there were upwards of 40 jeeps surrounding a small group of elephants.  One of them, "Broken Ear" was known to dislike jeeps due to one killing her baby elephant in the past.  Despite this the convoy of jeeps surrounded her, and after two roaring past she became increasingly angry. Our jeep was stuck - due to other jeeps blocking exit paths and despite being one of the furtherest away we were in her line of vision and she charged us, hitting the jeep twice.  It was very upsetting to see an animal so distressed and angry, she obviously felt she need to protect her herd which included a baby. It felt so cruel having so many jeeps invading her personal space It is a beautiful area but I really would caution anyone thinking of visiting
A beautiful national park in sigiriya. Hundreds of elephants, deers and wildanimals. The largest elephants group I have ever seen. Baby elephants are so cute. I will visit again and again.

We went here as part of our tour and had a great time. I was amazed at how many elephants we saw and how close they came to the jeep. When we started out there were a lot of jeeps in convoy but then we spread out and it was much better. A fun afternoon.

Took a jeep tour around this Park with a small group. You find out on the day if the elephants are more prominent here or over the road at the other National Park. We were worried because it started to rain just as we started but luckily it stopped pretty quickly. I thought we'd get very little in the way of sightings and only from a distance but it must be said I was very wrong. We got very close to multiple groups and even though it was Jeep city they didn't seem to mind, they mostly kept eating, which was amazing to see and exactly why we came. Such peaceful creatures (so long as you don't do anything stupid). The driver got us very close. We also saw a couple of peacocks and parrots but it was mostly about the elephants. I enjoyed seeing this more than the Elephant Orphanage as it seemed like less of a display.

We drove through this park en route to Girithale for the night. Our guide described it as'an elephant infested jungle'. It was a great and pleasant surprise to see an Asian elephant eating roadside, traffic giving it a wide berth. I was struck by its colours with a pale orange/pink colour above its trunk, behind its eyes, the trim of the ears, etc. This type of elephant is decidedly smaller than its African counterpart.

We visited on 28 December at about 11 pm with out two children aged 5 and 2. The safari drivers did mention that due to rains only a few elephants were sighted the previous day. After much discussion they still urged that we take the ride which lasted about 2.5 hours. The cost was about 13,000 LKR (5000 for the driver and 8000 for entry with taxes and rental for car.). Peacocks and butterflies were more commonly visible while an eagle and some other exotic birds in smaller numbers. Going one way (about an hour)  was exciting though while coming back the same route was taken and kind of felt dull because we knew the elephants aren‚Äôt going to show up anymore. Initially I was upset for spending that amount and not having achieved our objective of seeing elephants but then their movement can‚Äôt be controlled by the authorities whatsoever. It‚Äôs part of nature and luck. Very unfortunate though we will try again some other time in a season which is more suitable.

My wife and I visited the Minneriya National Park in late November 2019 as part of a Webjet package tour of Sri Lanka. The day included a morning visit to Sigiriya‚Äôs Lion Rock (which is impressive) followed by a 4wd tour of the park in the afternoon. We were in luck and came across several hundred elephants (guide said 300-400.... maybe) in about 4 or 5 large herds around the edge of the lake. Many babies were seen in different herds. We got within 50m of a few herds as they grazed and moved around the lake edge. Absolutely amazing! Apart from the elephants we saw a lot of bird life and a herd of water buffalo. There were probably 20-30 other 4wd‚Äôs sharing the experience so it can get a bit hectic. The elephants generally seemed to ignore the visitors. The only criticism is that our personal guide and the 4wd driver/guide didn‚Äôt exactly overwhelm us with information and stayed fairly quiet thru out. Overall a great day!

Nature lovers should go there, You can enjoy the amazing view and feel the calmness of the environment with group of elephants, But the uncontrolled Safari riders ruins the calmness. It is better to avoid this place on rain season.

Unfortunately I just say that this park is useless. First of all they ripping you of on the price since you foreigners second they start charging for the Jeep entrance which uoi are paying already separately from entrance fee . We came to Sigiriya during our roundtrip through Sri Lanka and stayed for two nights at a local homestay. Our plans were to climb Pidurangala Rock for sunrise and for the afternoon of our arrival we had hoped to do a kayaking trip on the nearby river. However, despite mentioned in Lonely Planet's guide, Rasta Rant does not offer those trips anymore. So, we decided to return to our accommodation and since we are quite new to Sri Lanka and it is our first time here, relied on the help of our hosts to arrange the Safari on short-notice, instead of booking an offer we had found on Air BnB. The trip for two people was quickly scheduled and a driver showed up in his jeep an hour later. After driving for a while, he pulled on to a gas station, where he asked us whether we were going to Minneriya or some other park. We quickly said Minneriya, as this was what we had asked for from our hosts. Once we got to the park, the driver (whom we had paid beforehand - 13,000 Rupees for 2 people as agreed with our hosts), went to the ticket counter. While he was gone, a man in what appeared to us as a park ranger uniform approached us and told us that today was a great day to see the elephants. When our driver returned, him and the "ranger" quickly exchanged some words, followed by him also getting into our car, shaking our hands and introducing himself. During the drive he seemed very knowledgable in terms of the different animals and birds, told us he has been working at the park for over 10 years and that he would know all the best spots to see the elephants. Every now and then he hammered against the side of the jeep to make the driver stop and show us something. Everything seemed fine, until at the end of the drive the "ranger" got up to ask us if we were "very happy" and mumbled something about "I really need the tips." That's when we realised that this man is as far away from an official ranger as possible. We passed him some money so he would leave us alone and after again exchanging some words with the jeep driver, disappeared into the woods. We already felt quite embarrassed that we had mistaken him for an official ranger, when our driver made us stop at a local vegetable plantation and encouraged us to buy corn. We kindly refused and were relieved when finally returning to our accommodation. Then, when we got out of the car, he claimed that Minneriya was more expensive than the initial quote and demanded an extra 2000 Rupees from us. We were completely confused, but ended up refusing and walking away from his vehicle. If you're planning on visiting the park - please make sure to compare prices, and don't make our mistake and fall for the false rangers. BUT: The park itself is beautiful, we had lots of close encounters with elephants and other wildlife, saw different kinds of eagles, water buffalos and jackals - which overall, was worth the hassle - so overall - we absolutely recommend visiting the park.

So basically we paid $100 au dollars all together including Jeep hiring. But it was soo beautiful and lovely to see wild animals without any animal cruelty. Worth every cent. Thankyou jayalath .

Had a half day visit to Minneriya. Highlight was around 30-40 elephants emerging from forest to 'take the waters'. An awful lot of trucks vying for best position, but got a good long view of several heards around the park. Lots of birdlife and buffalo also. A 'must see'.

I did a lot of research before taking this safari and was a little concerned about if the animals would be treated respectfull. As it turned out I was pleasantly surprised. Yes, there are a lot of jeeps but they all stay on the tracks and don't speed or chase the elephants. We went in the afternoon and saw loads of elephants and babies too. As well as that we saw buffalo, deer, langurs and many birds including sea eagles. As an animal lover this was a highlight of my trip to Sri Lanka.

Minneriya National Park was an incredible place and experience. The park is beautiful and we saw hundreds of elephants on our loop through the park. The drivers were careful and respectful of the animals.

This was our first (of 3) safari experiences in Sri Lanka.  The jeep was in average condition,  3 rows of seats,  with open roofs where you could stand up.  All the jeeps follow the same track,  up to 2 abreast at a time. You go through bush, then through a river (3 jeeps got stuck - fortunately not ours) and then it opens out to large areas surrounding the lake.   We saw a couple of hundred elephants (best to go on an afternoon safari as they come to the lake for water). Unfortunately there were almost as many jeeps as elephants and at first we sat in a huge queue (the jeeps at the front of the line didn't move on in a timely manner).  After a while the jeeps spread out and there were plenty more elephants to see,  with less crowded jeep conditions. Our driver didn't really talk to us,  but it was pretty obvious what we were looking at! If you're into elephants this is the safari for you.

Make sure that you pick the right guide. Some clearly just roar around as fast as possible in unsuitable vehicles. Others are great and gives you a detailed view of what's going on and get you really close.

We were left slightly underwhelmed. The park was very busy and there was a lot of jostling to get into positions. The variety of animals was disappointing, and every bird of prey was an eagle...... the elephants are in abundance and very docile so you get up close to them.
Great way to see elephants and lots of bird life. The driver was great, making sure we had seen enough before moving on again. Highly recommended

Sadly this wildlife park is being over-exploited, with convoys of jeeps in search of a limited number of elephants. When a herd was spotted, the dirt track turned into a 4x4 sales forecourt, with jeeps jostling for space and the best view. We also saw a few larger birds (egrets, eagles, herons and pelicans), and a mongoose. Ironically, we saw two elephants (one of them with tasks, quite rare) by the side of the road on our drive back to the hotel. Our driver was quick to spot them in the semi-darkness, and we were much closer to them than in the wildlife park. Our expectations may have been too high, as we had already visited Yala National Park earlier in our holiday. I would give Minneriya a miss and spend the extra time at Yala. A more diverse range of animals and birds, with less jeeps!!

Great park , you see Elephant really clearly. On my visit there was a herd with a 3 week old calf who was feeding. In another area another herd with a young calf who was trumpetting, I also saw Giant Squirrel and 6 times The Jungle Fowl Sri Lankas national bird. My driver arranged an earlier visit than planned to avoid the many jeeps on our way out there were many many jeeps. So if your goings get some good advice and go a little earlier.

Loved this adventure. Our safari had a fun start with one jeep bogged in the river. Then there was great excitement when we spotted our first wild elephant, then another and another. Then there were dozens of them gathering near the lake, one only a month old. Very special indeed.

I had no high expectations prior to our jeep safari but maybe by luck or chance we had a great experience. We did see a lot of elephants but more significantly was the fact that we saw them in herds of at least 40-50 with babies! The park is very open so we were able to get quite close, many photo opportunities. Also saw an abundance of bird life, water buffaloes, monitors etc. The safaris seem to take about 2 hours. Wear sunscreen as the jeeps are open top and plan to have a good long shower back at your accommodation to wash of all the dust! Great experience.

You can club this safari along your visit to the sigiriya rock. Your car will take you to the place from where the safari begins. You will sit in jeeps and trek into the jungles. The jungle is dark and at times the ride gets too bumpy. After a good 30-45 mins one lane trekking you will get onto a plain where you can see herd of elephants in wild. Its a cute sight. We also spotted peacocks, a wild bull who ran past our jeeps (completely safe) and a few birds of different species. We stayed there for another 30 mins. The elephants seemed human friendly. They were very near to our jeeps but they were of no harm to us. Getting out of the jeep is strictly prohibited. Pregnant ladies do not take this ride even if its your first trimester. I had my two kids with me. They loved and enjoyed the bumpy ride more than the elephants watching. Overall its a good experience but nothing exceptional about it.

Well worth going if you want to see elephants. I was happy if we saw 3 or 4, but we ended up seeing hundreds. At times elephants in every direction we looked. First 30 to 40 mins through dense jungle so you are unlikely to see anything, but then scenery opens up and in open grassland with herds of elephants. When we thought we had seen then all turned another corner and there were more. Also saw water Buffulo, a jacket and lots of birds including egrets, cranes,storks, peacocks and eagles

Beginning the tour we were apprehensive as to whether we would be fortunate enough to see any elephants - this wasn't a problem! We saw upwards of 50 wild elephants, ranging from 6 weeks old to fully grow males which we were told was quite rare to see. Definitely a must if you are in the area.
Saw soooooo many elephants! And several up quite close too! But make sure to pay for yourself at the entrance, don't leave it to the tour guide as it'll be more expensive.

I really wanted to see the Sri Lankan wild elephants, so I just ignored the experts opinion. Eventually I realised the consequence of my arbitrary decision. The best time to watch these wild elephant is July to end of September. But I went there in last December. But I was lucky enough to see dozen of elephants instead of hundreds. These Asian  elephants are more beutiful than the African ones. Safari started early as 7am. The guide and park ranger was very knowledgeable and know exactly where can find the elephants. also we saw few peacocks, pelicans, some other birds. After all it was really remarkable safari, enjoyed the dry zone wild life in Sri Lanka.
This place is famous among tourists as well as locals due to high population of elephants. Between May ‚Äì October, the dry season is the best season to visit there.

Starting of with the negative, dozens of jeeps! Otherwise, beautiful area and elephants, elephants, elephants. You‚Äôll get very close! So, must see when in the area, just don‚Äôt get bothered too much by the other jeeps.

No, not the elephants - the jeeps. Still, it was worth doing.

Yes, we saw a lot of elephants.  and more elephants.  and nothing else, unless you want to count the egrets and storks... But... there were TOO MANY JEEPS. Easily 50 deep at every sighting watering hole.  Way too many for any decent viewing or photographing.  More than I have ever seen at any other game drive we have taken in the last 40 years. :(

Amazing, amazing - was so excited to be able to see the elephants and other wildlife.   Tip...make sure you get a jeep that has proper tyres and that it is a 4x4......we saw two jeeps that couldn‚Äôt make it up the hill!  There are various companies out there that offer a trip and all look pretty decent jeeps and the really good thing is that they respect the elephants space and keep to the track.
It is an excellent National Park. There is a large lake and we saw many birds. e.g. Paradise Fly Catcher and animals e.g. Elephants and Spotted deer.

The park is definetly worth the money. We spotted many bird species, lizards, crocodiles, buffalos, monkeys and of course hundreds of elephants! But, at the moment there is no limited for amount of jeeps at the same time in the park creating massive traffic jams. That even led to a situation where the elephants could not cross their path! Please change the rules for jeeps and tourists to further protect wildlife

We visited the park whilst on an organised tour.  I love to see animals in their own environment, they look so much happier.  There are loads of elephants to see, water buffaloes and a variety of birds. The park is extremely busy with visitors and you can lose count of the jeeps. It is good there are tourists and especially if the money goes towards the upkeep and conservation.

A very nice safari to see elephants. We went around 2:30 pm as it‚Äôs the time for elephants to come to the lake for drinking water. Our hotel was 50 minutes away from Safari point and cost us 60 US$ to pay the local jeep to take us around.

But it's worth the visit.  The plains are beautiful and made more beautiful by the wild life.  We saw herds of elephants, lots of peacocks (including one doing a dance and 2 others fighting), pelicans, etc.  Amazing place
We were very early, at sunrise. We were the only ones in the park. We could see many birds, quite a few quadrupedes including elephants. No leopard and the like.

We went there around 2 pm and saw heaps of elephants - it was the best experience ever! I never saw elephants before in the wild life and it was amazing to see them. We went from Sigiriya and paid 5.000 Rupiah for our cheap but could divided it through 4. The entry fee for a group of 4 is 14.400 Rupiah but it is totally worth the money

We did manage to see elephants..  the attraction here... but the amount of jeeps racing around & jockeying for position was nasty! You‚Äôre just sucking gas fumes from dozens of jeeps around to see a group of elephants in the distance:( There‚Äôs needs to be a limit of vehicles per hour. So even though we did see elephants the experience left me disappointed! Mass Tourism at its worst!
Overcrowded but nice elephants to see near water with young ones. MANY jeeps rushing all over the place to position themselves for best position!

All of the coach trips seem to do 10am and 3pm excursions, meaning the park is packed to the rafters with jeeps just after these times. We had a hired Tuk Tuk and so arrived independently. As soon as we arrived, we were approached by several jeep drivers, all offering to drive us for 2-3hours for Rs4,000. We chose a friendly driver, paid our entrance fee and entered the park. Our drivers English wasn‚Äôt incredible, but he was clearly interested in the wildlife and so we were able to converse well and we both thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Some of the drivers were clearly going off-track, but ours was conscientious. We saw so many elephants on this trip.  Unfortunately there are way too many jeeps too and some of the drivers hog their space if there is a good view.

Minneriya is the best place to see elephants. You can see hundreds of elephants in Minneriya national park. Minneriya is the biggest elephants gathering national park. You can book a safari jeep and go closer to Elephants. You can see elephabts behaviours. All most all the of the tourist love elephants. This is one of the main activity all tourist love to do.
What a beautiful place! Saw sooo many elephants and water buffaloes. Highly recommend visiting this park!

We did a jeep safari tour as part of our Sri Lankan tour and we had the most fantastic day we say hundreds of elephants in their natural environment just doing what elephants do,  there were several herds and we also saw some babies  that were only a week or so old, we also saw water buffalo, and pelicans, deer and lots of other birds. It was a spectacular afternoon made all the better by our guides.

My wife and I visited here during our recent Birdwatching Tour of Sri Lanka üá±üá∞. We chose to take an afternoon Safari Drive as we‚Äôd heard that it wasn‚Äôt so busy then, hmm I‚Äôd hate to see how busy it was in the mornings üòÇ. Most people visit the park for the wild Asian Elephants üêò and they were impressive. However, our main interest was the bird life, which was extensive and impressive. Several rare and sought after species are easy to see here, Lesser Adjutant, Spot-billed Spoonbill, Paddyfield Pipit and Jerdon's Bush lark to name a few. The Asian Elephants üêò did steal the show. The place is a must for anyone visiting the area. Highly Recommended

Fantastic afternoon with the wife on a safari trip. Saw all sorts of birds, monkeys, lizards etc. But the highlight by far was seeing 200+ elephants all playing, eating and washing in the reservoir. Amazing experience!!!

This is my 3rd time on Minneriya Safari and had different experiences each time. So you must be lucky enough as well to witness the best safari Life as well. You can go beyond the Water path and have a good experience only once I was able to go to that part. So talk with the driver to get the best experience. Mostly Elephants are there. lots of birds are available as well.

Minneriya national park is a great place to see hundreds of elephants in a single place. This is where I saw the most number of elephants at a time in a single place. Best time to go is the evening as elephants come to the lake. Apart from the elephants you can see some other species like deer, wild boar, buffalo, etc. Be alert and get some information from your guide or any other local in the area about the crowd in the park as lots of crowd will ruin your experience.

It was great to see such large numbers of elephants in the family groups - matriarch, babies, youngsters, teenagers. Then with the young males who had been kicked out from the herd just feeding a short way from the main herd.  Interesting to watch the antics of some larger males finding their way into the smaller herds to check out the females. Yes there are a lot of safari jeeps but it did not seem as chaotic as in the Yala National Park and I think this is due to the fact that this park has a rather large open area of grass around lakes that allow for the army of jeeps to park by the road and allow for viewing by everyone as there were elephants everywhere.  In Yala once an elusive leopard is found, it's a race on for ever driver to get their clients a sighting and the tracks are narrow and not as open as in Minneriya. I loved watching the babies, and yes the protective mothers keeping their bodies to the jeep side, but both continued grazing whilst we looked on. Watching elephant behaviour was interesting -  a mother comin out from a bamboo thicket as we approached in the jeep.  We stopped. She stopped. She waited - we didn't move.  Then obviously when she thought it was safe, she signalled to the two younger elephants and one by one out of the thicket they came and crossed the track. I didn't feel the driver of our safari jeep hassled the elephants at all.  All the jeeps seemed to give them the space. If the elephant came behind the jeep, the driver stopped, waited for the elephant to pass or do what it wanted, before the driver proceeded along the track   The park appears to have designated trails that the vehicles can use and the jeeps generally stated on this track or to the side if they needed to pass. Its main purpose for this park I think is for wild elephant viewing, but we also saw lots of birdlife around the lake. We did an afternoon safari from 3pm and I found the seats were very nicely padded in our vehicle but seatbelts I think are optional, but then I was standing up a lot when the vehicle was parked or moving slowly along. It's not for everyone as it's hot, it's bumpy, but I enjoyed it.

Did afternoon/ evening safari here. Over 250 elephant which we were able to get quite close to. Lots of young one too. Long queue to get tickets but our driver did the hard work for us Recommend for families as well as groups.  All the children we saw seemed to be really enjoying it.

I‚Äôve to start acknowledging that my first experience on a safari was two years ago in Lewa Wildlife Conservancy Camp in Kenya, a stunning location with breathtaking game viewing and an outstanding respect for wildlife. Therefore, my standards before taking part in the Minneriya safari tour were very high.  Having said that, I have to recognize I would never recommend this place to go on a safari. For many reasons. First of all, because you will start the tour with dozens of jeeps leaving at the same time. Then, the feeling that the safari is not meant to offer you an experience with wildlife by watching the animals in their natural habitat, but to give tourists the chance to get the snapshots they need to share with their friends on the social media. But the main reason I would advice to avoid this safari is that, although most of the jeep drivers (like ours) were professional and respectful to wildlife, some of them showed any respect at all for either the environment or the elephants. At one moment, we saw 5 jeeps off the road blocking a group of elephants, and preventing them no just from moving away, but from moving at all. If the park allowed less vehicles at a time and enforced stricter rules on how to approach the animals, as they do in other parks, it would be an enjoyable experience we all would benefit from.

We were at the afternoon safari which started at 3 pm and it was high season. The jeep had no seatbelts and the driver drove very dangerously so we had to hold on to the metal construction of the car. We were all sore at the end wirh our hands dirty from the rust. However, the main problem was that there were 100 jeeps (with 2 or 3 people) chasing 1 or 2 elephants. The area of the park is quite small, so imagine 100 jeeps racing to get the closest to the animal, going off the roads and through the jungle senseless. At one point the jeeps completely surrounded a mother with a baby. The jeeps didn't even turn off their engines and made so much noise. This is not ethical. This is not connecting with nature. This is not sustainable. This is taking advantage of animals and the environment. Yes, we saw elephants, and it was beautiful, but the animals were just numb and lethargic and no wonder why.

I went on an afternoon Safari as part of a Gate1 tour. The jeep guides knew the best places to see the elephants and we were not disappointed, seeing several herds both at a distance and close up. The park was extremely crowded though with a lot of jeeps, so if possible check with the locals first and try to go during a less crowded time. That aside, it was amazing to see all the elements in their natural habitat

We we‚Äôre staying in the park in order to reach sites within the cultural triangle, Sigiriya, Dambulla and Polonoruwa, it was amazing  to see elephants in the wild even just walking down the highway great authentic experience.

"Very Unique Experience "  plenty of wild life Elephants aplenty. Take plenty of water, caps, umbrella, binoculars,  if possible. Beautiful scenery & birds. Booked our tour through Minihini Hotel. Thissa & his staff were FANTASTIC. Thank you  guys. Cheers Glen W Melbourne Australia

I went  in February. I think what I experienced there happens in most of the other parks close by like Minneriya or Kaudulla. Anyways he driver decided in which park the most elephants were expected. The few elephants there were surrounded by eight jeeps or more. The problem is that they don‚Äôt fill up the jeeps with people so there is mostly one Jeep per person or per couple. Jeeps crowd chaoticly around an elephant and sometimes the driver couldn‚Äôt get through or just drives by because there is no space to stop. Fumes and noise from the jeeps were constantly around me. I saw more animals outside in the country than in this NP. Not sustainable activity, no animals or nice nature observed, dusty, hot, polluted and crowded with people and Jeeps. Not recommended at all.

Our grand'children were delighted to see wild elephants, buffaloes, peacoks, big monitors and cameleons  ...But the adults became annoyed by the traffic jam !  So many jeeps!...Better to be there at the low season....Anyway a bit of rain and mist made the scenery  dreamy, beautiful.  I suppose that we are a bit spoilt by many safaries in Africa.

Wow what a great after noon. Set off for a three hour safari and when we were finished we had seen approx 45 elephants in total. Many mothers with thier babies and a few old Tuskers. Very enjoyable and a must do.
really remarkable.  Take the evening visit - starts at 130 pm.  Not too crowded and so many animals. Take you camera but you dont even need a long lens!

Had a private safari tour of the park and we were not disappointed. There were Peacocks and Eagles in abundance and we also saw lots of small groups of elephants. Definitely worth a visit if you want to get up close to the elephants.
We saw a number of Elephants, Crocodile and Buffalo as well as some very rare birdlife. We had an afternoon and early morning safaris. Both worth while

We decided to add it to our trip on the way from Polonnaruwa to Sigiryia and did an afternoon safari. There were a ton of elephants and it was a fantastic experience. I think a jeep tour in a private jeep was $100

I would not recommend this tour. Too many jeeps  coming too close to the elephants. At one point, there were close to 20 jees surrounding a mom and her baby. We saw many elephants and other wildlife. the jeep was comfortable and convient for taking photos. The trip lasted almost 3 hours. Great value.
This experience was poor. Inexperienced drivers drived too fast to the elephants along with around forty other jeep drivers. I can tell here safari service is bad.

This was the worst safari I have ever experienced! Thousends of jeeps - in every jeep only two people. The jeeps don't stay on the roads. If they see elephants they drive wherever they want - without worries to destroy the National Park or if there might be nests of other animals. Please go to Udalawale to do a safari and not here - there they stay on the roads and respect the animals and nature! Cost a lot of money and not worth it. Far too many vehicles with drivers driving like mad men. Hardly saw and Elephant only in distance. In the morning driving on the highway one was right on side of road. No other animals either. Waste of US$100

We saw lots of elephants, and the park is a nice setting. We visited at 8am and only saw a few other jeeps in the park so completely contrary to some of the other reviews here. It took around 90 minutes to find an elephant. This experience was terrible. Inexperienced jeep drivers driving too quickly to the elephants along with around forty other jeep drivers. Avoid this not least to give the elephants some peace.

This was a terrible experience. They call it a jeep safari but it is mostly a jeep rodeo.  Drivers jockeying to get close to the elephants. 30 jeeps surrounding 6 elephants revving their engines. Sad.

We did not see nearly as many elephants in Yala. Don't bother with distant photos with half hidden elephants as you will see plenty up close.

Do your local research before falling into the arms of the first jeep driver!  The elephants move between three parks and are sometimes never here.  Wonderful if you're lucky, but the large number of jeeps does not enhance the experience.

It's nice to see elephants here, in natural habitat and not in "prison" but apart from elephants one can see very limited number of other species (not only for our trip, but generally that's what we have heard).

This was the most disappointing part of our Sri Lankan tour so far. Scores of jeeps kicking out fumes chasing  the Elephant. No information given had no idea where we were going other than following other 4x4's .

Convoys of jeeps travel into the park in the search for wild elephants.  Even though we were out of the gathering season, we saw several groups of elephants, including young babies, at very close range.  It was fantastic.

Took a safari from our hotel. Most of the vehicles have up to four seats, and there are loads in the park all it appeared searching for the same herd of elephants. We got see elephants close up but, in hindsight, would have passed this up and just done the safari at Yala National Park. Yala has a lot more to offer.

Relatively smaller national park in sri lanka. Can visit from Habarana or Dambulla. Large number of elephants (in hundreds) can be seen in the evening, specially during dry season. We had pre-booked our safari and met the driver at 3pm.  It was busy going into the park but the jeeps soon dispersed.  We saw loads of elephants, peacocks and monkeys. Yes you will see elephants in their natural habitat, however you will also see too many jeeps surrounding them. So cute! We run And run into The jungle to find elephant... And thanks to our guide, we saw Them!!!! To do!

So upset with the Safari this afternoon I agree with the man that lives in Kania it was a shambles. Most enjoyable part of the 14 day trip to Sri Lanka. Had bit of excitement with an elephant. Everyone should go on an elephant safari.
