When finally we reached a herd of elephants, the poor animals were already surrounded by way too many jeeps. It felt sad, with most tourists making too much noise and taking selfies with the elephants in the background. Really disheartening.

The whole experience is very staged and disappointing. The problem is that the vegetation is very high and dense in the park, so while you do see elephants and other animals, they are usually far in the distance and you can only see them through lenses or binoculars. Also the variety of what we saw was very limited. After about 2 hours, all of the jeeps then take you to a large look out point high on a hill. While it was beautiful, again you can only see animals far in the distance unless you get lucky. It all seemed very stage like a Disney-world, andino in the final scene. Don‚Äôt waste your money! We later went to Udawalawe National Park in the south and it was spectacular. we saw numerous animals and birds very close up. It also cost us far less...$30 per person compared to $50 in Minneriya.
We Saw very special places.Great Tour and very friendly Guide. We can highly recommend Lalith Safari Dambulla
We spent a couple of hours in a large 4 wheel drive viewing many elephants of all ages here. The terrain was interesting if a little boggy (it rained overnight).
mostly elephants can be seen although there are quite a few herds of migratory birds nearyby, I hope they have more species to be seen for a change,
Don't go expecting to see loads of different types of animals. We saw plenty of elephants and this was amazing seeing them in the wild.
We did an evening safari at Minneriya national park, and there were an abundance of elephants. There were quite a few trucks in the park but it didn't detract from the elephants.

It is no so much of a safari as it is a large bunch of tourists loaded jeeps rushing to see the elephants. At some point there were twice or tree times as may jeeps as the elephants they surrounded for the benefit of their clients. If you've ever been on an African safari forget about this one, or you will be sorely disappointed... Bear in mind that you can actually ride an elephant in Sigiriya, if you so desire.

It‚Äôs wonderful to see all the elephants. I arrived early afternoon, around 2pm. There were maybe 50 elephants, by 4pm there were 200. They just kept arriving in various family groups, walking out of the forest for kilometres along the lake. I‚Äôve been to Africa and have not seen this many elephants together at one time. Really was something I‚Äôll never forget.

Saw nearly 20 odd wild elephants during the tour. The best time to go the safari is around 3.00 p.m. This will give you a great a chance to see lot of wild elephants because they travel to drink water to river. Safari jeep drivers will take you close to the wild elephants. So dont be scared and just enjoy the moment with those giants.

We were lucky to see many elephants and not get stuck in the mud in the park because our touring driver knew an excellent company who use 4 wheel drive jeeps. The company is part of the Mihini hotel on the main Polonnaruwa road at Habarana. Our jeep driver was Nimal and he was excellent at navigating the rough and very muddy terrain . We saw two other much swankier jeeps stuck in the mud waiting for rescue because they are not 4WD. Don't be fooled into getting one of those. Nimal is a local guy and knows a lot about elephants. He also managed to get us away from the other jeeps so a lot of the time when we saw elephants we were on our own which was a much better experience than being in a traffic jam of 8 of them. Highly recommended and seeing elephants in the wild and beautiful setting was very special.
we went to safari at morning  we sow more deer and  beautiful lake and lot of birds  but only 05 elephants  there relay beautiful place

column7: The Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, UK
column11: Large convey of Jeeps/ Land cruisers etc explore the park in search of Elephants. Very rough terrain particularly after heavy rains. A joy to see a herd of 12+ Elephants just eating and roaming.
Could see only handful of elephants after going around the park for close to 2 hours. It was a close encounter and my 1yr old was really excited.

The "Ecco Park" is supposedly a sanctuary for wild elephants but it has now become completely over-commercialized by greedy Tours firms all congesting parts of the park in their diesel polluting vehicles. We were on an organised trip that lasted several hours much of which was spent in traffic jams of vehicles all travelling along the same track but often several lines abreast and in different directions as individual drivers each sought to outdo the numerous other vehicles. Some broke down or attempted ridiculous "three-point turns" in the track only to become stuck in the mud thus causing various blockages. At one point we didn't move for nearly an hour. Imagine a crowded street full of tuck tuks all vying to get to the same spot and not caring about the chaos created and the effect on the elephants. Most importantly the Elephants' space isn't respected so they were sometimes chased by selfish drivers. It was an appalling experience for the animals and the far too numerous visitors alll congested into very tight areas. Website photos suggest large open spaces and numerous elephants enjoying the peaceful sanctuary but instead we saw a mere handful and on each occasion they were quickly approached from various directions by numerous jeeps. It's just become a commercial rip off for greedy firms. Overall it was chaotic, disrespectful of the elephants and an appalling excursion. Avoid!!!!

We came to the park to see the elephants which we saw, they were in a pack witch was lovely to see, it was a beautiful day for us just being with them in there nature setting. Would love to come back.

Sri Lankan safaris are perhaps the cheapest on the planet compared to Africa, but do understand, you will be in a queue of vehicles, the drivers will all be communicating with each other to get their convoys close to any animals spotted. On our safari the Elephants were clearly upset with being intruded upon. One of the vehicles got bogged and the Elephants were being quite aggressive. The interpretation from our guide was little more than "look - there's and elephant" He certainly was no naturalist. The national park was certainly beautiful, and it was nice to be out in the bush, but I would not describe this as an "eco" experience. Sri Lanka has a way to go to offer true eco tourism experiences.

great place to go in November when not so many jeeps. lots of flooding so we accessed from the Kaudulla side. Elephants, jackal, wild hare and lots of birds. Nice to see them behaving naturally in the wild

It is the largest concentration and gathering of Asian elephants that can be seen anywhere in the world. We did an open top Jeep safari, watching baby elephants playing with each other, bull elephants tussling for dominance and the great matriarchs surveying the scene is not a sight you are likely to forget in a hurry. Inside the park you will also come across some wild boar, peacocks, deer and many more animals roaming freely as nature intended them to live. Aside from the elephant, Minneriya is also home to some 23 other species of mammals a paradise for many species of Lizard and you will see them here in all their colour if you look carefully enough. the views are stunning. You'll see hundreds of birds, storks, pheasants, beer eaters, herons, pelicans, eagles, etc. There are also spotted deer‚Äôs roaming around. The driver was knowledgeable and would point at different species.  as well as snakes like the Indian Python and the Mugger Crocodile. Above all, of course, are Sri Lanka‚Äôs wonderfully varied bird population. We drove for over an hour seeing birds, butterflies, tortoises, deer‚Äôs and when we thought viewings were over, we saw a young grey leopard. It was just breath-taking. Then more Stunning scenery and you will also encounter deer, buffalo, pelicans and peacocks. Despite the heat it was a great afternoon at the park. The drivers are constantly in contact with each other and updating where the elephants are to be seen. I highly recommend this to everyone.
... too many jeeps around the elephants which can be seen in very large numbers , but unfortunately the park has not been limiting the number of tourists so far ...

August 2016 was when I visited Minneriya and I have never seen so many elephants, mostly as my visit had coincided with one of Asia's top wildlife experiences; the Elephant Gathering, where more than 300 all gather; truly something worth seeing. Other animals were water buffalo and many birds, such as egrets, pelicans and the lesser adjutant stork
Lovely setting and one of the best parks in the region to see the wildlife. The wildlife do travel between the two main parks so ensure you know which park to visit

My sister and I went to this park in mid Oct. Before setting off, we were told by the tour guide aka jeep driver that we might see peacock, buffalo, many species of bird, etc in the journey. Eventually we could only see big group of wild elephants. It was impressive to witness a crowd of 80+ giants in wild which totally opened my eye. This was my first safari experience so I found it eye-opening. However it was the second safari visit of my sister and it disappointed her a bit comparing with her last visit in Udawalawa national park in the South of Sri Lanka. She saw a lot of peacock on tree, buffaloes, many birds in beautiful colors on top of elephants and to her the Udawalawa visit was more a memorable experience than Minneriya. For those who are planning a visit around the country, would recommend to visit other sizable national park where may have higher chance to see more wild animal instead of just elephants. If your trip cover just the middle part, this safari is still a must-go!

We were lucky enough to visit Minneriya National Park during The Gathering. This is a natural event that happens between June and October when elephants migrate to Minneriya for the protected area and large lake. It still depends on the day you visit but we saw over 200 elephants and a magnificent tusker who gave us a show bathing in the lake. Many new babies that were so enchanting to watch. Don't expect to be the only person in a safari jeep in the park... there will likely be many. We spent over 3 hours there with our driver and saw so much. We also encountered a water buffalo stampede with hundreds of them running right across our path! It was an unforgettable experience and one that I will treasure for years to come.
In There we Saw Bunch of Wild Elephants.Many Species of Birds,Monitors and many more animals.Good time to visit this Place in May to September.

Minnesota is but a short drive from Habarana where we were staying at Winmi Resort. The resort owner arranged for his driver, Sanjeev, to take us to Monneriya in his keep with an open or closed back. I had expected that there would be a limited number of vehicles and visitors permitted along a specific track so as to allow for an ordered viewing of wild animals from a respectful distance. What we got instead was a mob, an unruly mob of over 250 keeps of every size, carrying from 1 to 6 people. Most, perhaps 80%, had just two people! As was our case. The drivers often communicated with each other by cellphones and were respectful to each other. The poor animals, almost all elephants, were relegated to third class gawking status hemmed in by jeeps who at times prevented them from grazing freely and reaching the lake, their ultimate destination that afternoon. I have been to wildlife reserves and national parks in many countries over 6 decades, and Minneriya was the worst, the most pedestrian in wildlife management. It was clearly a cash grab for the park and for the jeep drivers. It was a disgusting sight to see over 200 vehicles going here and there over new and used tracks, just chasing after groups of elephants, with a total lack of respect or concern for these sensitive animals. Sri Lanka should be censured by the World Wildlife Fund and various UN and International bodies for this sham of a national park. Humans 100, elephants 0. A bloody shame. Foreign visitors would do well to boycott Monneriya for now until the Sri Lankan authorities get their heads out of the well of greed. Boycot boycot boycot.

We saw more elephants here and nearby outside than anywhere else in Sri Lanka. The elephants were really relaxed and were mooching around indifferent to us. I would however share the concerns about the number of jeeps and their proximity to the animals. They really need to introduce some daily limits to the jeeps.

A two hour jeep safari. A wide range of wildlife but the highlight was, of course, the free roaming elephants. The drivers are constantly in contact with each other and updating where the elephants are to be seen. Absolutely amazing to be sitting looking an elephant in the face from 10 ft!
I loved Minneriya because the animals were unharmed and were in their natural habitat. It felt like a different world during the safari. I highly recommend this to everyone.

It will be interesting to see what happens in future as they are building a tarmac road just about up to the national park. It was great to see the elephants up close but they really need to educate the drivers more they formed a whole line blocking the groups of elephants actually getting over to the water hole at one point and one elephant was getting agitated and moving towards the jeeps to protect the small baby elephants which is completely understandable. Our guide told us in the peak period there are over a 1,000 jeeps in the park- more jeeps than elephants.They really need to get the balance right- It was interesting to see some groups of elephants waiting in the trees for the jeeps to go at sunset before starting to come out down to the water hole. Good experience but they need to get the balance right otherwise the elephants will withdraw. Interesting to also see cattle grazing and eating grass in the national park- the elephants food too....
I visited in September when the elephant herds gather in this region. On our safari we saw approx 150 elephants which was an amazing sight. One of the highlights of my visit to Sri Lanka.

We went in open jeeps to a place where there were a large number of elephants of all ages - it is said that there are over 200 elephants in this park. The jeep ride is bumpy and those who have back trouble will be advised to sit on a front seat An afternoon well spent!

Booked a Jeep Safari to see the Elephants & we saw sooo many Big & Small, the Jeep ride was fun & the Elephants were sooo close, we have been to Africa before but saw a lot more Elephants here in their natural habitat, it was really nice to see all the different terrain as well.
if you like elephants than this is a must! We were lucky to see hundreds of elephants of varying ages and it was an absolutely brilliant. Would highly recommend.

Did a safri here and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. We travelled in open top jeep so you could stand up and really take in the sights. Big open areas and lakes where the elephants go to play and drink in the water. The elephants wander around ignoring all the jeeps so seems quite natural instead of seeing them in a captive situation. Before We went there, I just thought we would see a few elephants and it would be no big deal but I was wrong. we seen about 150 and quite a few Calves as well. One of the high lights of our SL holiday. Saw lots of birdlife as well .

Well worth a visit. We visited both Udawalawe and Minneriya and if you‚Äôre only able to do one then 100% do Udawalawe as it‚Äôs way less tourist crowded and you get more up close to the elephants without actually disturbing them. At Minneriya we were lucky enough to see loads of elephants, probably 100 in total but there was easily 100 jeeps all vying for the best view and its gets really chaotic. The elephants just want to get to the water and with the jeeps all in a line they almost block the elephants which doesn‚Äôt seem very animal-centric. We didn‚Äôt pressure our driver but you could see other tourists pushing their driver to get in front of others for a better photo. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, a beautiful place and the elephants are magnificent.

A must do on our agenda! Piled into the back of jeeps (5 seats) & headed into the national park on a fine day with the roof open & no side wall giving great views. The driver was great driving along & spotting various animals in the bush and grass. The highlight took a little time with us seeing various monkeys, birds & water buffalo before finding the elephants (a couple of large herds). The elephants were amazing - probably 50 to 80 in total & they were so carefree despite our close attendance.  At the busiest time there must have been 50 jeeps & 4wd's parked up with cameras clicking amongst many excited people. The elephants mainly ate grass however a few entered the lake. We also ascended a small tower for better views over the countryside & lake - be careful as no handrails. Nothing special but part of the tour. Took a bit of a drive back to the bus/car park where we met numerous monkeys & a couple of relatively tame deer.  Great fun even for the older less mobile folk in our group.

Much smaller than Yala, this park is home to large herds of elephants and we managed to see lots of them as well as buffalo and several peacocks. I was surprised by the large number of jeeps in the park, but luckily we had arrived a little later in the afternoon and most were heading back to the park entrance enabling us to have a relaxing 20 minutes observing the elephants with only one other jeep in attendance. A beautiful experience.

Don't go to other "sanctuaries", visit Minneriya if you want to see elephants in their natural environment, thriving, playing and reproducing in a healthy setting. We did a 3 hour "safari". There's not a huge amount to see apart from elephants, but there are lots of then and you can get close to them (closest was about 10 metres from the jeep). The safari is basic but fun, you park in the car park, climb in the back of a jeep and get driven around the park to seek out the elephants. We went in the afternoon as that's when they are most likely to congregate at the lake. Our jeep driver was very good, the two of us bounced around in the back - just two side benches, three padded cross bars to hold onto if you want to stand up. No Health & Safety here - hold on tight to avoid bashing your bits against the side of the jeep, and if standing, duck to avoid branches thwacking you in the face! Remember sun cream as there's no cover, and a hat is risky to blow off if there's wind. We saw loads of elephants - noisy, playful, muddy, but and small. There was one suckling it's mother, still a bit pink, that our driver said was about ten days old. We did this as part of a four day tour which originally had the elephant sanctuary in its itinerary, but switched to Minneriya before we travelled. We are so pleased, as people concerned with animal welfare, opposed to elephant tricks and rides and tethering, but still wanting to be close to the magnificent beasts.

In short, yes you can see elephants as long as you enjoy being in a traffic jam of at least 30 jeeps with diesel engines on and completely stuck with alpha male drivers not giving way to anyone. They cut across the elephant herd who were left on either side calling to each other. One hopeless safari member of staff. Think twice about going. Went to Ude Walawe which was a  much better experience.

As Harry‚Äôs first safari this was a special experience and it did not disappoint! There were so many elephants and it was only the beginning of the annual gathering. We even saw a baby elephant only a few days old, still pink and drinking milk from its mother. Amazing.

We saw plenty of elephants, although probably there were a few more jeeps than elephants! Our driver was really good and didn't get too close or follow them if they chose to walk away. Some elephants especially the young males seemed quite keen to come and look at us. Watching them was fascinating and a very special experience.  We also saw hundreds of water buffalo and loads of birds. In particular the storks, pelicans and spoonbills in very large flocks were spectacular and a fish eagle hunting was entertaining.  The Jungle Fowl was cool too, very pretty. If its a clear evening, get your driver to stay as long as possible because the golden light is amazing just before sunset.

Lots of elephants. No predators. A couple of different wetlands which attract elephants, buffalo, bird life and the occasional mongoose. If you want to see elephants, this is the national park to visit. We had a driver/ tour guide Sangeeth Gayan who organised our safari for us.
In Minneriya, you can see lot of wild elephants at one place. There are playful baby elephants as well. Apart from that this is a good place to watch some birds as well

If you want to see lots of elephants this is definitely the place to go! We say a few herds in a variety of places and seeing them playing in the water and enjoying themselves was truly spectacular. There were some baby elephants who were only a few weeks old which was amazing. The downside was the hordes of other safari vans and people in them. There was lots of congestion at the points were the elephants were and it did impede the experience slightly.  Some of the behaviour of other vans and the people in them left a lot to be desired and at times got to close and upset elephants. Nevertheless it was a lovely site and one I wanted to see and would say don‚Äôt miss the experience!

Went on a jeep safari as part of our Sri Lanka tour. Wonderful to see so many Asian elephants but it felt like the drivers were chasing down the elephants! There was nearly as many jeeps as elephants and it didn‚Äôt seem much consideration was given to the wildlife, elephants especially. We have been on safari in Africa where there is a 2 vehicle limit to protect the animals from over exposure, this was certainly not the case here. Concerned how much of the money raised from the safari actually goes to the protection and conservation of these endangered animals, I believe it probably goes to purchasing more jeeps!! Would not give them my money again until I was convinced a large percentage was being used for conservation purposes. Their tactics and approach should be monitored by animal welfare groups to ensure it is in the animals interests.
Tough off road trail but well worth the effort. Elephants ,crocodile,Monkeys plus much more all in their natural habitat. This is a must do

Nothing much except for elephants. 10 times more jeeps than elephants. traffic jam. bumper to bumper and 1 saw 2 accidents because the drivers just do not want to give way even in front of wild elephants. Elephants are nice. you must have time to watch them in their natural habitat. Mostly eating. occasionally playing. Kids can loose interest easily. Other wildlife worth watching are birds if you are into them. Entire experience is marred by overcrowding.Sadly, no quota control.

We saw around 200 elephants and had awesome sightings including 2 week old calves, pregnant mothers, tuskers - and were also able to closely observe the manner in which these herds interacted. We saw calves at play, mothers disciplining calves, elephants bathing/ eating and elephants protecting each other/ their calves from the noisy and disruptive jeeps. It is indeed worrisome that the behavior of these jeep drivers is beginning to resemble that of the drivers in Yala. These drivers were clearly more interested in letting their clients take selfies up close and personal to the elephants than look out for the well being of these animals. Three herds had finished playing and bathing in the lake and tried numerous times to cross over to the jungle. But the jeeps had hemmed them in. Despite several ‚Äúwarnings‚Äù on the part of the matriarch, the jeeps did not budge - and I remain surprised at the patience of these gentle giants. The wildlife authorities need to take immediate action and resolve this situation if we are to preserve one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs greatest heritages.
Definitely go if you love elephants. Make sure you tip your guide a little so they take you good spots as well.

We knew that the herd flitted between Minneriya and Kaudulla but heard there where elephants at the former. There are literally hundreds of operators out of Habarana and I think most hotels guest houses either run or know someone who does. We went with our stay Sagiriya Water Gardens and the guy was excellent, we even saw a single elephant on the way to the park. Once at the entrance you have to pay for each individual in the jeep and there is a discount for jeeps with more people in so a couple will pay slightly more than a jeep with four and so on. Once in the park it takes a while to reach the lake but we saw multiple elephants on the way, then two herds of about 30 elephants at the lake ranging in age and size from cute little ones to one of the largest who was only one of two with tusks. What an incredible day, and our guide held right back and kept a good distance, where we saw others too close.

We were almost bitterly disappointed as the park was closed on the day we wished to visit due to an employee strike, however it was resolved on our last day - worth checking that there are no such issues when you are planning to go. The elephants gather early morning and during the evening, so going in the middle of the day will end in disappointment as the elephants head into the jungle. Worth booking in advance to make sure you get a good time slot. The gathering is a daily ritual, so seeing elephants is highly likely. The round trip is approx 2 hours, including about 30 minutes to get into the jungle lake where the elephants gather, so you can spend around an hour watching the various herds/families gather. It was a great experience, and a "must do". The elephants are not confined to the park. When returning to our hotel after dark, we saw an elephant on the road side, eating, so keep your eyes open!!! We were lucky enough to get our own jeep, and they are comfortable. Drivers are knowledgeable and enthusiastic.

You can book the safari in advance online or ask your local resort to assist you. Special jeeps for the park. Seats 5-6 each . Awesome views of the elephants as well as the other wild animals. Don't miss their evening congregation by the waterbody.

There are 3 parks in haberanan we visited this one and kaldoulla.  The elephants had migrated to the latter which, therefore attracted all the traffic. Minneriya was peaceful and the more attractive with a wealth of bird life alongside a herd of 30 elephants and beautiful scenery.  You‚Äôre in the park for around 2.5 hours. Terrific.

My wife and I enjoyed the visit to the Minneriya National Park with the exposure to nature and her habitats. We took the afternoon session. While we didn't see as many elephants as others had experienced there were also fewer jeeps. It could be the timing and day or how thirsty the elephants were. We had also spotted monkeys, peacocks, eagles, and buffalos. Note that one cannot get off the jeep once inside the park, so please make sure you have your toilet break beforehand, and bring your sunglasses, sunscreen, and some water to hydrate. It's an unique experience.

This was mind blowing seeing the Elephants in the wild I would recommend this to anyone kids and adults It is very safe We went in jeeps with heaps of opportunity to take lots of photos There are around one hundred or more elephants and to just see them in their natural habitat was awesome

Minneriya is reputed to be the home of the largest herd of Asian Elephants, and our experience in April 2017 would seem to bear that out. Despite the commercialisation of the trip - there must have been 50+ Land Cruisers around the reservoir - the park is big enough to give one a good view of the herd, especially as it gathers in late afternoon before going into the forest to sleep. They came from all around, to drink, wash and play in the shallow waters, before setting off in a column and heading back into the forest - and they were so quiet. No squealing from the baby elephants, nor thudding of feet from the adults, but simply an inexorable susuration as they walked past us. The area is also home to many other species, and we saw many types of bird, including the omni-present egrets, ibis and other water fowl. There are also crocodiles, and we saw a couple basking on the banks. A great experience.
The highlight of our trip to Sr Lanka. Too many elephants to count. We went for the afternoon safari and it was far superior to both Bundalla and Yala safaris.

We visited here during our visit to Sri Lanka and it was the highlight of our holiday. The whole experience was fantastic, we saw lots of animals on our trip especially lots of herds of elephants including baby elephants which were all really close to us in our jeep. Fantastic experience We also had a brilliant guide who talked to us about all the animals and provided us with binoculars. üòÄ

we went from Kandy. it takes only 2.5 hrs. we stayed in a hotel in Habarana and came to the park at about 4.30pm. by 5 pm near the lake you ll see lot of animals and can watch them till late... so interesting. not that violent as well.

We had an amazing afternoon at this National Park.  We arrived mid afternoon.  Could not believe how many elephants we saw.  Herds and herds by the lake.  So great to get so close to families with their babies and to sit and watch them in their natural habitat.  Yes lots of jeeps but plenty of room to experience these beautiful animals in the park.  A highlight of our trip to Sri Lanka.

This was a highlight of our holiday. This is a very large National Park.  The number of elephants of all ages strolling across the grassland around the huge lake was incredible.  We felt very privileged to see such amazing sights and at very close quarters too.  On the advice of our guide we entered the park in mid afternoon and the number of visitors was much lower than at other times of the day.

For us, this was better than our trip to Yala national park. We saw 70 elephants gathering as opposed to 2 lone Male elephants at Yala. And we got lucky, we saw a leopard, we didn‚Äôt at Yala. I understand that Yala is a huge area in comparison. Our guide was very professional, caring for the ecosystem here and extremely knowledgable - the guide joins your jeep and is included in the entrance fee to the park. Enjoy!
Loads of elephants - more than we could count.  Shame that there were loads of jeeps too.. Pick up a jeep safari from nearby Habarana
The Minneriya national park very famous for Elephants but there are other animals And birds. Since it is located near the lake. pelicans & eagles around the lake

Here you have the chance to get up really close and personal to the wild elephants. We saw a family of 5 and it was amazing, as well as seeing other elephants along the way. We were under the impression beforehand that we would see hundreds of elephants but unfortunately this was not the case, so don't get your hopes up. This did not ruin the experience as it is really amazing to see wild elephants so closely in their natural habitat. We saw about 11 in total. There are also other animals here to see such as lizards, iguanas, monkeys, water buffalos etc. We spent over 3 hours in the safari but the time flew by. A must do if you are in the area.

We organised our own jeep and transport to the park. We arrived earlier than we initially thought we would which worked in our favour. It took a while for our guide to find any elephants but when he did find them there were only about 5 other jeeps around giving us exclusive viewing of these beautiful creatures. When it was time for us to leave the park we came across another herd of elephants but they were surrounded but a huge number of jeeps - I would say more than 50. If I‚Äôm honest, I‚Äôm not sure if this is very ethical, I know everyone wants to see the wildlife but I think the amount of people entering the park needs to be limited. We also saw lots of different birds and lizards. All in all a very nice trip.

Even with the large number of jeeps, it was a very special experience to see so many wild elephants.  It really impresses on you how social elephants are and how lonely those single  working elephants you see around must be. Best moment was seeing a two month old baby and its mum with a security detail‚Äô of older females.

We went in the late afternoon and saw herds of elephants by the lake.  A fantastic photo opportunity, as we didn't want to visit any of the elephant orphanages having heard about the way some of the elephants are kept. It is a shame to see so many jeeps all speeding round to find the elephants, but to be fair they are only doing what we as tourists want, which is to find us a good view of the elephants! As we were leaving the park we came across a small herd completely by themselves and with no other jeeps around, our driver switched off the engine and we sat for a while watching them, it was the highlight of the afternoon.

My wife and I arrived at Sigiriya and saw the crowds and cost to climb it and decided we would go to Meenniriya instead. Definitely a good call! We saw around 25 elephants, countless buffalo, a samba dear and a chameleon. Best to go in the afternoon. A great experience.

One can rarely get to see this gathering of Asain elephants else where. It is one of the largest in Asia. the safari can be quite dusty. One needs to have a hat, sunglasses & something to save yourself from the muddy dust.

Simply a must. Ensure you get s tour guide that has local knowledge and speaks good English. Gets very busy and a shame you can't pre book tickets. Take something to keep the dust out of your eyes/mouth. Gets very busy which kind of ruins the whole experience as all you see is about another 100 jeeps all racing to the same spot when wildlife is seen.

I am not an elephant person.  Never have been.  I would see an elephant or two at the zoo and be ..... meh.  But Minneriya ... ROCKED. MY. WORLD. It starts with a 30 minute ride in a jeep from the entrance into the heart of the national park.  The roads are good, you can stand up in the back of the jeep and you are racing through the jungle with the wind in your hair; exhilarating!  And we hadn't seen our first elephant yet! During the next three hours, we encountered lone male elephants (who challenged our small jeep for dominance), a young mum with babies in tow (who was determined to chase us away to protect her babies) and then a herd by the lake.  The herd must have been close to 200 elephants; the sight was mesmerising.  Groups of elephants bathing, males warily standing apart watching the jeeps and each other, baby elephants running excitedly from group to group tooting their little trunks.  It was the most gorgeous experience. And it is not just elephants, we also saw flocks of birds, a herd of water buffalo and one crocodile sub-bathing. A brilliant afternoon, we loved this experience so much that we almost considered going back a second time!

This is the highlight of my Srilanka trip....timely in their annual The Gathering......and being able to see more than 100 elephants in the wild..... I travelled solo and was a joiner on a safari tour.
Worth to see,Luckily we were able to see group of elephants including baby elephants too:-),peacock,buck. Best time to visit after 3.30 noon,it will take around 2 hrs for full coverage.

I have been so looking forward to this and it exceeded my expectations! We were picked up from our accommodation and had a 20 minute drive to the park entrance. The roads inside are bumpy and dusty but we were by ourselves for quite a while and it did take a while to find a family group. We stopped and just watched in awe as they ate and move a bit and are some more. We moved on and saw some deer, monkeys and a turtle sunning itself then turned around and the group of elephants had trebled in number. A lot of other jeeps did join us and it got rather crowded but everyone switched their engines off and just enjoyed the view! I felt really privileged to have had this experience and definitely recommend!

We made the huge mistake of starting our safari at 12.  We thought the park was quiet.  We ended up understanding why!  We saw ONE single elephant in our 3 hours tour, and we saw him about 100m from the exit!   None of the other jeeps we passed had seen elephants either.  Talk about a major disappointment, for our 3 kids and us!  I know it‚Äôs nature and you can‚Äôt control it,  but I would‚Äôve appreciated if they could have mentioned the best hours to visit, at the entrance of the park.  When we got out of the park, there were many, many jeeps that were coming in .  Hopefully for them, and they saw more elephants than we did during the day. The entrance fee was 11,000 roupies for the 5 of us (2 adults + 3 children) + 5,000 roupies for the jeep/driver, so this was a very expensive outing. We got to see monkeys, birds and buffalos, and the scenery was memorable.  But the lack of elephants was too.

The safari was a wonderful. To see so many elephants in their natural habitat was a real treat. Bring sunglasses and a scarf to cover your nose, and be prepared to be filthy when you are done, as the trails are dusty. The kids absolutely loved it.

We‚Äôve been lucky enough to travel extensively and go on safari across Africa (and have avoided private reserves), and whilst there is a great opportunity to see Elephants (Peacocks, monkeys and buffalo). The limited road/track system and volume of vehicles (at one point on our visit there were 40 trucks watching a herd of 20 elephants) means this is more theme park than wildlife experience. However, saying that, the context and countryside is beautiful - but we couldn‚Äôt help feel that the herd were slightly penned in.....
You can enjoy the beautiful landscape, it reminded me of Africa, there is a lot of wildlife, specially elephants bt you can also see buffaloes, peacocks, crocodiles, monkeys and more!

Wow, wow and wow! I have been on safari in South Africa before but never have I seen herds of elephants congregating NATURALLY in their hundreds. So close you could almost touch them but there of their own accord and not through force or any sort of zoo/conservation set up. Nature at its absolute best. I highly recommend this nature reserve to all! You could sit there all day just staring and would never get bored. Such majestic animals without humans on their backs or chains around their feet. Playing in the water, eating grass and just being elephants!
A great safari trip! Saw lots of Elephants and other animals close up and from a far. The park was very environmentally aware and are doing a good job to help wild animal populations.

Although we hired a private Jeep it wasn't quite the intimate experience you imagine. Transfer to the park from the hotel was swift, I'm fairly certain our driver was trained by Lewis Hamilton. Entry to the park is chaotic with the car park heaving with other vehicles waiting to get in followed by a long wait to start moving along a dusty track bumper to bumper. I never imagined eyes watering with dust & exhaust fumes that you would see anything but our expert tracker seemed to know that if there were 30 or so jeeps huddled together there might be something worth seeing. Once you see the elephants and there are plenty including some only weeks old, all you can do is focus on  them. They switch off the engines and you can watch at close range as they go about eating with their young rolling in the mud.We even saw some tuskers that the guide said are quite rare. It was a good afternoon & although they probably allow too many vehicles in I wanted to go as much as the next person & enjoyed being so close to the elephants.

We hired a jeep through our driver (Ceylon insider tours) and decided to do the safari late afternoon as he advised that is the best time to see elephants as they come to the water just before sunset. As soon as we entered the park we saw an elephant at the side of the road. The paths are very bumpy and dusty and there were many other Jeeps, making it quite an exhilarating experience. We spotted a few elephants on our way through to the water, then we were absolutely delighted when we saw several groups gathering by the lake. Some bathed but most grazed. A couple of elephants walked right in front of our jeep. As the sun set we saw two large elephants with tusks. It was a brilliant experience. Highly recommend it.

I made the trip to the National Park in July 2018 and saw more than 100 elephants combined all together! Other than elephants I saw some water buffaloes as well. I managed to get a Jeep for 4000 LKR from Sigiriya. I also paid 4500 LKR for the entrance fee for one person. The system works in a way that you pay lesser if you have more people entering the park in a single Jeep. So going solo into the park is the most expensive option. Try to get a few fellow travellers to share the Jeep, if they don‚Äôt mind, to bring down the price of the entrance fees.
A must visit, not to miss is you are going to Sri Lanka. Being among literally hordes of elephants, up close.

I went her in a group of three one afternoon. We were told by our hotel owner than the afternoon is better than the morning for seeing animals. We paid 16,000 for the jeep rental and guide. This was for hotel collection and the whole tour. We saw so many elephants, even a baby one that was only a week old! We also saw water buffalo, eagles, cows some birds like a peacock and some monkeys. The afternoon was brilliant. There were lots of other jeeps but they all seem to be really respectful of each other so you move around them and they move around you. Overall a really great day
Nice park to go for safari early morning 6 am we loved because of only 2 jeeps in the park and rherefpre it was a really good expieroence of the  ature of Sri Lanka.
Our first safari ever, nice ride through forest to a big lake, some buffaloes and at least 150 elephants. Some got really close to our jeep.

We went there on Lonely planet's recommendation, hoping this park would be less touristic and more respectful then parks like Yale. I don't understand the high rating ‚Äì I know from discussions with locals that our visit was not an exception. We could not really enjoy when we saw several families of elephants totalizing probably a hundred ‚Äì we rather were impatient to leave. Why? 1. at that place where the elephants gathered, I counted 40 jeeps. We thought we stay and the rush would stop, but no, the queue behind us was endless. What an absurd approach: you go to see peaceful nature and wildlife and you see more jeeps than elephants, hear more jeep noise than birds singing, smell stinking diesel gas instead of flowers, plants or elephant poo. 2. The jeeps go so close to the elephants that they get annoyed by it and run away (sometimes less than 10 meters). It is fine for me when the jeep stops a hundreds of meters away and the elephant gets close, but not when the jeep gets closer and closer so that tourists without cameras or binoculars can shoot stupid selfies with their smart phone. And even less when they cut their road when they go to the water or even following them when they calmly run away. We are nature and elephant lovers and were so keen to see them in the wild for the first time (we got close to them only during a volunteering mission in a refuge for domesticated elephants). And we were so sad and keen to run away when we actually saw them. I understand elephants are part of Sri Lanka's tourism industry, but cannot accept that elephants pay the price ‚Äì they paid already too much.

Went for the elephant safari, mainly for the kids, and they were not disappointed. We saw lots of elephants, closely, and also spotted monkey, eagle and som buffalo. Long ride into the woods to get the elephants, but exciting for the adults to stand in the jeep and enjoy the ride. Remember to duck, or you will get slapped by branches.

Great safari for a couple of hours in the afternoon. Our excellent driver Dilee from Louis tours organizeda driver and took us for a ride. We saw over 250 elephants in great big herds. Wow what a thing! Recommended!

We booked a Jeep Safari into Minneriya Wild Life Sanctuary in the afternoon, where we saw herds and herds of Sri Lankan wild elephants in their natural habitat. Inside the park you will also come across some wild boar, peacocks,  deer and many more animals roaming freely as nature intended them to live, The elephants gather at the waterholes for drinking and bathing their young and immersing themselves in the river. It is incredible how close these wild elephants come to the jeeps with people aboard, They are very interesting to watch as they wander right pass you and go about their business.

Must go on a safari st Minneriya National Park Wild Elephants everywhere up close Bird life amazing our guide was brillant even spotting the smallest of lizards Truly a memorable afternoon we spent in the park.

There are a huge number of elephants and you can get very close. We saw a baby that was only a month old, and it was amazing to see how protective the females are. Plenty of other wildlife int the park as well make this a really worthwhile visit.
What a beautiful place.  We saw many elephants.  They were close and playing in the water.  Really nice safari.  Was not too crowded either which made it even nicer.

National park with safaris. You can book a safari in advance but you don‚Äòt have to. At the entrance you find a number of jeeps waiting. We paid 3000 LKR for the jeep, 7500 LKR entrance fee for two persons and 1000 for the guide (english speaking). Compare this to the prices of organized tours and decide yourself. The guide told us the morning tours have higher chances for smaller animals (deers, monkeys etc - the leopard is only very seldomly seen) and some elephants, in the afternoon rides are for elephant sightings. We started at 1 pm. Be prepared for adventures, our jeep got attacked by an angry male elephant!

It is also the most beautiful and the place where animals can walk freely, and the park is home to the highest concentration of leopards in the world, and it is also an important sanctuary for Sri Lankan elephants and aquatic birds. Monkeys, crocodiles, and other critters run around the park‚Äôs grassy plains and forest areas.

Its been one of the best , most beautiful experiences I have ever had ! Nishantha, our guide and driver was amazing and also very thoughtful towards the wild life in the park, always being mindful not to disturb but also offering us a wonderful experience. Its been great being able to see the animals in their natural habitat, I would always recommend that you visit the park in the afternoon, it is the best time!

We went just wanting to see elephants in their natural habitat and we were not disappointed. Saw small groups, larger groups, in the forest and in the open lake area. Our jeep driver was very respectful of the elephants and their space, some srivers were not. We also saw a lot of other animals, many different birds (a nesting  flycatcher much to our guide's delight!). Was a great sfternoon.
Safari was a good place to visit and seeing the elephants was nice. Its amazing how the national park is managed.
So many very cute elephants in one place. Worth seeing it !!!  Its an adventure with four wheel drive!

Overall jeep quality and driver awareness and friendliness were just nice. You have to be prepared to get a bit too deep inside the park to see herds of elephants. Don't be disappointed to see the loners at the start of the safari and get too anxious way too early. :-) I should say the safari drivers who don't seem well educated were far more cordial and courteous.

Our driver Chathu from Sri Lanka Wide Tours arranged this at short notice with his friend Amila, a jeep driver at the park. The 2 of them really made this a great experience but you really have to get over the sheer volume of other jeeps at the waters edge where all the elephants congregate to get the most out of this. There were alot of elephants to see including a family with a week old baby. You could watch them all for hours and its a great setting with the lake as a backdrop. Amila managed to get us off the beaten track and away from the masses for most of the trip where we were able to see a variety of birds, monkeys, lizards and deer. There were no bears or leopards to be seen but elephants are what you come to see here for the most part. We came across a wounded elephant alone in the bush on the way back. Apparently the park was aware of it but inter-departmental politics and red tape was preventing something being done about it. The elephant was clearly in pain. Chathu and Amila both called the ministers office in Colombo while we were there and ended up getting something done about it. The calls were flying back and forward to Amila. We were very impressed by his tenacity in trying to get something done about it.

I am not much of an animal-lover myself. I had planned this visit for my daughter, but the experience of watching the elephants in their natural habitat was just so thrilling! It was a pleasure watching them graze and we saw over a dozen baby elephants too. Initially, we were confused between Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage, Millennium Elephant Foundation and Minneriya National Park, but this was our best decision. Watching the elephants at the other two options is akin to seeing them at a zoo while this is like being part of a Discovery episode :-)
