Amazing to see so many elephants in one place, but it was so busy when we were there with other tourists. Jeeps everywhere which did spoil it. We visited some other safari parks later on in the holiday that were much quieter, and for us, a much more authentic experience
Amazing jeep tour in this national park full of water buffaloes, grazing elephant families, many species of birds, lizards, etc.

This park is just off the main road from Habarana to Polynaruwa. We took a jeep "safari" ............. which means you stand up in the back of a jeep, holding on to the roll bars. Nothing much to see as you enter down a dusty track - but then it opens out to a flat area by the lake, where there are a lot of elephants ..................and a LOT of jeeps! Some of the jeep drivers could do with better training, as they get too close and spook the animals - but its still goo and there are plenty of birds to see by the lake. Not really a safari, but quite an interesting drive around for around 2-3 hours. The good news is that they only allow the jeeps in between 6am and 6pm - no night time drives .................but there are a LOT of jeeps. They need to be careful or they'll spoil this by unregulated commercialism.
This NP is interesting from july to october. At that time you Will encounter group of elephant. Next to elephant you wont find too many different species of animals

We had a great jeep safari there and our aim was really to see elephants. We managed to see about 100 elephants including quite a few baby elephants. The park also has a variety of birds should you be interested but it was not our top priority. We went for safari around 1:30pm which was quite unusual time (normally either 9am or 3pm) but that meant that there were not many jeeps around which was great- perhaps a bit hot but wear appropriate clothes and sun cream and it will be worth it! The tour was organised by our hotel and we paid Rs16,000 from Dambulla hotel pick up

We were staying in Habarana and had pre-booked a safari in this National Park with Walkers Tours. In short, this was a fabulous experience. The jeep picked us up at the hotel then took us about 20 mins down the road to the park. After a short delay where the driver bought the tickets, he drove us into the park. Pretty much immediately we saw spotted deer then we drove through the jungle for about 20 minutes down to Minnerya Tank and saw roughly 80 elephants in abou 10 different groups (or some were alone). We also saw a huge variety of birds. Our Walkers Tours guide was hugely knowledgable about the bird names, elephant ages etc. We never expected to see so many elephants in a 2.5 hour trip. Brilliant!!

Sadly fo us it was a rainy day so we didn't get to enjoy as much as others probably do. I heard that you are likely to see more animals when raining but the whole condition was not so satisfactory for a wild life tour. But I'm sure that it's amazing on normal conditions though.

Minneriya National Park is on the way to Polonruwa, just around 10 Kms from Habarana town. You have lot of options from jeep drivers and hotels, guest house who can organize the safari into the national park. Its best to visit the park in the afternoon at 3 pm as you have better chance of sighting elephants & other animals, birds in the park. The Jeep safari should not cost more than LKR (Srilankan Rupees) 3500-4000 for the entire jeep. The entrance tickets to the park is steep but worth the price. The jeep can seat easily 6 persons. Check out the jeep before you agree on confirming the same. Go for Jeep which is more open type with good space to stand and view the wildlife. Some jeeps have 2-3 rows of seats which makes the jeep cramped and no space to stand for viewing animals. The Park has dense population of elephants. You are sure to sight elephants at close proximity specially near the lake within the park. Apart from Elephants there are quite a few birds you can sight near the lake and water bodies within the park. The safari is for 2 hours and almost all the Jeep Drivers are knowledgeable about the route within the park and places to sight elephants. The Jeep safari has a pit stop at lake where you can get down and take pictures. There is tower near the pit stop to get views of lake and park. Overall a must visit place if you are staying in Habarana or near by place.

Had a very low expectation on a very hot afternoon when we started this trip. And very soon we were staring at a large herd of elephants! Great herd to keep watching. Park is highly scenic, lovely lakes and meadows.

Finally managed a life-long dream of seeing elephants in the wild with a visit to this National Park. It is an amazing site however they do get crowded & surrounded with many safari jeeps which seems unfair on the animals. The park is a huge wild expanse and a great experience.

Great 2 hours saw around 50 elephants from 3 days old, infants, juveniles male and female. We were very close so lots of pics. Yes pricey at $70 aus but so is everything.  Driver was good and overall a great adventure
I would recommend to go to this park early morning or late afternoon. Animals are more active. Great place :)

its a very nice park situated 5 km away from habarana junction, the best time to visit is around 2 pm (afternoon ) there is a nice big lake middle of the park,  elephants go there to drink water, other animals like birds, bull , rarely can see crocodile,

While visiting Sirigiya, we decided to visit Minneriya National Park and it was the best decision we could make. I have seen but reviews of people saying it was crowded. It must have been we went late during the day, but we just came across 2 more jeeps in the whole safari We arrived just after 3pm. We were travelling with locals who arranged a safari driver that was at the entrance for only Rs3000 (bear in mind that you may be overcharged if you don't have someone to negotiate it). The entrance fee is almost none for locals and quite higher for foreigners, but still quite reasonable. We started the safari and were able stand up on the jeep and get amazing views. The first part of the route is a dense forest, but when you reach the opening, the views are stunning. You'll see hundreds of birds, storks, pheasants, beer eaters, herons, pelicans, eagles, etc. There are also spotted deers roaming around. The driver was knowledgeable and would point at different species. We saw elephants far away, then, a lonely one 50 meters away and then we came close to three, i.e. a mum with the two kids. We were totally amazed at seeing wild animals at less than 30 meters away and suddenly the protective and caring mother charged at us. It was terrifying yet astounding. The mum just wanted to ensure that we didn't hurt her kids. We drove for over an hour seeing birds, butterflies, tortoises, deers and when we thought viewings were over we saw a young grey leopard. It was just breathtaking, but the young fellow disappeared before we got our cameras out so it only got imprinted in our memories. Overall, we spent 2 hours enjoying beautiful views and spotting some of Sri Lankan amazing wild life. Highly recommended.
Minneriya National Park is amazing, you can see 100 elephant in a one group, in the raining season they move to Kaudulla National Park, and also so can see many endemic and non endemic birds.

We did an afternoon jeep tour and it was amazing. We saw two whole herds of wild elephants including a number of babies. Was so magical to see them so close but also in the wild rather than tied up/being ridden. We also saw lots of monkeys and birds. The reservoir area is beautiful.

My wife planned to ensure we visited the elephant reserve whilst in Sri lanka. We were not dissapointed with the 4x4 jeep drive into this great reserve. IOur guide estimated we saw approx 150 elephants ranging from raging bulls to 1 week old baby . We also saw babies buffalo, Jackals, Sea Eagles, Fish Owls and Peacocks to name but a few. Great experience, Great day 10 out 10. Doug and Julie

We had an amazing experience on our tour of the Wildlife Park.  There were hundreds of elephants to see and admire.  Our family loved it.  We enjoyed the open jeep ride and thoroughly took in the expereience

We were staying at Habarana and its a 15 min drive to the entrance of the National park. The ticket price calculation is a bit weird as all price lists are displayed in the local language only . Three of us in a JEEP cost me SL Rupees 9840 as entrance fees for us and jeep driver  plus SLR 5000 for the jeep rental . Wish the prices were better explained in English as is done at other places. We were lucky to have the services of Kavinda Thushan (kavindathushan888@gmail.com) who ensured that we moved in at the appropriate time ie 3pm and saw atleast 3 large groups of wild elephants , including a solo rogue tusker. All in all we would have seen 70-80 elephants. It is a bit tricky as there is another national park , across the road (name starting with K) . Elephants keep on moving and there are times when sighting wud be nil in Minneriya as all elephant herds would have moved across the road to the other park. We spent time till 5:30 pm in the park and saw elephants of all sizes from very small babies to large tuskers. Water buffaloes also inhabit this park and so do peacocks , monkeys and other animals. There is a huge lake inside the park called Habarana lake which attracts all wild animals. Definitely worth a visit. Take your camera and binocs as they would be handy.

Came on this safari with my partner and our 3 youngest - who absolutely loved it.  We saw plenty of elephants - both on the grass and in and around the water and managed to get some great photographs.  We also saw plenty of birds and our guide was able to spot where everything was and drive us as close as he could.  Had a really enjoyable time.
It was at the beginning of January and we were lucky it was not very crowded. We were able to see many elephants and birds. We were lucky to see a massive python which had swallowed some animal.

If you intend to see a lot of elephants enjoying in their natural habitat, eating, drinking and having fun, this is the place for you. Our driver had a contact for the jeep safari and thus we didn‚Äôt book in advance. The park is vast, full of greenery and spread across nearly 9000 hectares. As it was a weekday, there were not much people, just a few jeeps doing the safari. The site of more than 60-70 elephants at one place, enjoying their time, was really beautiful and satisfying. Plenty of playful baby elephants seen!! There are a lot of bird species as well in the park. Our safari driver was sharp-eyed and knowledgeable, spotting and identifying birds at a distance and stopping to let us take photos. The safari took nearly 2.5 hours to complete. All in all, it was worth the price paid for!!

We visited here with sigiritrip tours, the park is very nice every where is green and at the end of the park we see a very big lake animals come there to drink water and bathing. Everything is very special for us.

If you want to see elephants in the wild Minneriya and Kaudulla are the places. A 15 minute drive to the first opening revealed more than two dozen elephants spread all over the watering hole. Babies and mothers and "teenagers‚Äù. We also saw a great array of birds including an eagle, pelicans and storks. This is a superb place for kids to learn about wildlife.

These days there are very few elephants at Minneriya park but it is a great destination for bird watching and bird photography. The best time to go is around 6am or 3pm when birds are most active. The park is open from 6am to 5:30pm. Entrance tickets cost between Rs. 850 for 2 locals to Rs. 6,000 for 2 foreigners. The park is small so a half day safari is more than enough. A safari jeep hire cost is between Rs. 3,000/- to maximum Rs. 3,500 for a half day tour.

This is a great national park if you're interested in seeing Elephants in their natural habitat. From memory, the price was reasonable and totally worth it, because during our 3-4 hour stint, we managed to see circa 50 Elephants. The Jeep used was very comfortable, and the tour guide was helpful. Definitely one to recommend.
Jeep safari around a wonderful Great Lake. We saw so many species of birds including 3 types of eagle, water buffalo and so many elephants. There were 47 in the main herd we saw.

We saw lots of elephants, monitor lizards, peacocks, wild chickens and loads of birds. There is lots of other visitors but the park itself is beautiful. It surrounds a large lake with hills in the back ground.

There are monkeys, various species of birds and water buffalo a plenty to get you excited but we were very fortunate to see two different elephant herds at close range. The first was a reasonably large herd which were by the waters edge. This herd had many adult elephants and three young tuskers. The second herd crossed the road directly, and very close to, the rear of our stationary jeep. They were almost in touching distance, amazing animals to get so close to. Again we were lucky enough to see yet another mid aged tusker. It is advisable to cover yourself up well and to use plenty of sun cream as the jeep is open top and the sun is unrelenting. A must do activity for anyone lucky enough to get the opportunity to do so.

When we visited late afternoon in late March there were dozens of elephants making their way from the forest to  the lake and we were quite close to them. In addition there is a lot of spectacular bird life around. The park has leopards but are rarely seen so do not expect a viewing.

Our Jeep driver with five of us aboard took us along some very bumpy tracks but knew where to find the elephants which were plentiful including many babies, either in the scrub or by the water. We were able to go quite close to the various herds which was exciting. Only saw a few deer but it‚Äôs the luck of the draw. Birdlife too was prolific and so colourful especially the Indian Rollers with magnificent blue wings seen as they flew away. Painted storks, herons, kingfishers and cormorants were also spotted. Despite the heat it was a great afternoon at the park.

We did an open top Jeep safari, pre-arranged by our travel agent so no idea what we paid. It was a great experience, far quieter than some of the other reserves that we went around on our trip which made it feel very authentic. The downside was that we didn't actually see many animals! We were realistic to understand that's the nature of safaris so didn't let it spoil our day and we enjoyed the beautiful park anyway. On the drive back to Dambulla, a wild elephant walked across the road in front of us which made up for it!

We love wildlife, especially elephants. Have experienced encounters with them in many countries, for us seeing them tied up, & taking tourists for rides doesn‚Äôt sit well. So.......if you want to see elephants being elephants this is a must do. Words can‚Äôt describe the exhilaration when you see these majestic creatures appear. MAGICAL. For 4 of us Rs 15000 AUD $120, the majority going to the government! Our guide truly loved his job & was so enthusiastic at showing us every animal in the park. Including big monitor lizards, eagles , peacocks, monkeys, hornets nests, fantastic, didn‚Äôt see any leopards but over 200 elephants was good enough!

We‚Äôve been on one safari in india to see tigers and have left dismayed and poorer because it of course is down to luck and on on both occasions saw nothing more than a bird or monkey. So the thought of doing a safari to possibly see elephants was not top of our list in Sri Lanka. But our driver said we wouldn‚Äôt be disappointed so we gave it a go. First impressions great - we had our own jerk and driver. None of the group squeezing into one huge jeep for twenty with limited views. As we entered the National Park and drove around for 15mins I started to recognise in myself that desperation you feel looking for anything, something to make you think you just MIGHT see an animal. After another five minutes we slowed down and poking its head through some palms was a huge elephant munching on some food. That alone left us happy and content as it had already surpassed expectations. Amazing We then drove around the corner and found ourselves surrounded - literally surrounded by a herd of about 300 elephants. All slowly eating and gradually edging toward a lake for water. We saw families, babies and even rare tusked elephants (apparently only about 6% have tusks here). Words cannot describe the experience. We slowly drive around with them for an hour finding it hard to pull ourselves away. We eventually did to drive around another corner of the lake only to have another herd of about 200 doing the same. There is nothing more amazing than watching the sunset and these amazing animals calmly go about their business with no fear of humans or the Jeep and most importantly in their natural habitat living wild. Make sure you do this. It was an experience of a lifetime and the highlight of two weeks in Sri Lanka
Loved this tour. Lots of guides and cars exploring at once but was fine. Hopefully elephants weren't bothered by our intrusion. There were dozens and good to see them in their own habitat

Great, smaller safari to get up close and personal with the elephants. There were tons of Elephants to see and we were able to get really close to them, as there weren't too many jeeps in the safari. We also saw water buffalo... but naturally we cared more about the Elephants.

Visited here as safari trip in the afternoon.  What a trip never seen so many elephants occasionally just a mother and her baby then a single male elephant followed by a whole herd by the lake with several in swimming.  Our drivers stopped every time we came across some elephants enabling us to take many photos.. We also so lots of birds as we drove back to the exit.  A very worthwhile trip.

We saw more than 100. Elephants. Some of them in the lake when they bathing our driver stopped every where to take photos also we had some selfies with many elephants there are other animals birds, deer , fox . Very nice tour
This is the place where elephant gathering.if you want to see the elephant this is best place in Srilanka.. largest elephant gathering in Srilanka.. make sure to confirm Sunny days

Despite the hundreds of other vehicles, witnessing the gathering of about three hundred wild elephants was a magical experience. We saw water buffalo, peacocks, rabbits and many birds, too. The ride can be bumpy and dusty, and it is advisable to bring plenty of drinking water and a hat. Our driver was very skilled.

I ha been to many safari parks in Africa, I Nadia and Sri Lanka and this beats them all for elephants. Not much else of great note - many birds of prey,buffalo and monkeys, but the herds of elephants with lots of. Abbie‚Äôs is awesome in the pm when they come to the water. We saw hundreds and they were all in very good condition. So if that‚Äôs what you are looking for come here!!

There were a lot of cars the day we went and all the drivers stayed close together when they saw elephants. You need to control your driver to go a bit further even when there is less or no elephant : the park when you're almost alone is beautiful and just before sunset the light is amazing. The experience is not very expensive and for us was halfway wonderful !

I'm giving this a 'poor review' purely because there are far too many jeeps allowed into the park.  There are road pathways which don't have to be used. The elephants natural environment is not respected in such a way the jeeps can drive extremely close to them.  We witnessed a couple a incidents where the elephants became agitated trying to protect their babies and charged at a jeep. We left soon after, one less jeep in the park would be better we felt. The park opening time are 6-12 & 2-6.  Two hrs free from diesel jeeps should be extended for the welfare of the elephants.  Wouldn't recommend.

This is place where you can watch lots of wild animals so closely. Specially wild elephants. Lush green forests makes you feel fresh and lots of lakes to see. This is must visit place if you traveling Sri Lanka.

Visit to this sprawling park saw in excess of 200 elephants in there own environment . Large family groups which was a joy to see . Numerous other wildlife but elephants are the real star turn. Can be a bit bumpy in parts but it is a natural park so goes with the territory .

We spent a half-day here having booked a jeep and a guide.  This was definitely worth it as they are expert at spotting the bird life and the animals.  We saw sea eagles, storks, herons and a variety of other Sri Lankan birds, monkeys and elephants.  There were in excess of 150 wild elephants and it was possible to get really close to them.  The jeep was open top and perfect for photography.  On a hot day take plenty of sunscreen.

This is a fun safari. It is not a big park and we did see our share of elephants.  There is also plenty of bird life as well.  There is a lake and the elephants had clustered around.  The road can be rough, especially I would imagine in the rainy season.

It is certainly the output type of a large stream of tourists with a multitude of 4 x 4 which follow each other and intersect on the Park.We booked the jeep with our driver. its more enjoyable and good educational. Our Driver Harsha arranged very good jeep and driver.  Forget that and look at the landscape, nature, colors, birds and of course the final with the elephants. This was our first experience of elephants in their natural environment. They were many and did not seem disturbed by all the cars they approached even very close. The drivers try to respect their peace which also makes their stock in trade. We had the chance to see many places and many. This will be a great moment.

Amazing experience seeing so many Elephants and their babies in their natural environment inside the national park. We got very close to the animals. The jeep drivers were very good and we got a long time to take photographs and admire these incredible creatures. The only criticism I would have is that there were a lot of jeeps all near the elephants at once and although the elephants didn't seem to be bothered they should consider staggering the jeep times.

Yes, there is one large herd of elephants, some buffalos here and there. And you WILL see more vehicles than elephants. Most noticeable voice you will hear is those cranking engines, which are prolly overdue for their oil change. If you try really hard, you could mentally edit out those noise and jeeps to feel the nature. And If you have ever been to Kenya, like one of us was, you should save your hard earned money and skip this place.  Everything was a bit too much bonsai like. At the end of our safari, we did feel sad for these elephants who had to inhale so much exhaust fume everyday.

We took a jeep safari to this park.  We saw monkeys and various birds including kingfishers and peacocks.  The most remarkable sight was the wonderful herd of elephants.  There were easily over 200 of them quite close together.  I don't know the collective term for jeeps, but there was probably as many of them as there were elephants.  At one point we were grid locked (literally a few feet from several elephants) as vehicles have to keep to a single marked trail!  Fortunately, the elephants did not appear to be bothered by the congestion.  This is a wonderful park to see elephants close up.
We had a great 3 hours in the park. We saw so many elephants we were actually getting bored of them! I'm estimating 3 herds of around 30 or 40 elephants per herd.

Having not seen any elephants in Wilpattu NP in the NW, we were keen to see one or two here.  Everyone got very excited when we saw one as we entered the park. As we continued we spotted a large nest up in a tree, but no signs of birds.  30 mins later we arrived at the edge of the lake to around 50 elephants, including some younger ones.  After 30 mins watching this group we carried on and around the corner were another 100 or so.  Several in this group were only 2-3 weeks old and SO cute!  We spent another 30+ minutes here and watched the first group come over to meet the second group with their trunks up, which means they come in friendship.  Two young males had an interesting tousle eyeing each other up, rather like young stags during rutting. As we started to leave, we returned past the birds nest and an adult crested hawk eagle was feeding its dominant chick.  The other chick was smaller, but clearly there was enough food for the adults to feed both.  We also saw a male peacock displaying from both sides, and finally a crested serpent eagle as we were about to leave. A memorable afternoon.

You really don¬¥t want to do this... 30 Jeeps -14 Elephants All the car emgines were running while the cars stood there - and we were all in a cloud off waste gas looking at few elephants that we disturbt.
We saw a lot of elephants near a very big lake. Beautifull to see. There were about 200 elephants. The only thing they do is eating but the rest you feel watching this giants

Recently spent the afternoon at Minneriya National Park and it was truly worth it, we loved seeing the elephants up close and they looked so happy, we was extremely nervous about coming to Sri Lanka and seeing elephants being mistreated like they are in certain parts of the world with them being beaten etc to ensure that someone can have there 10 minutes off happiness to ride them so when there to see they wasn't being pestered as such just watched this is recommended.

We saw two large herds of elephant totalling nearly one hunderd when we visited. It was a wonderful experience. Watch out is that we were one of 30-40 jeeps all enjoying the experience. There are other reviews mentioning only a couple of elephants on show. If there are still 30-40 jeeps trying to view a small number of elephants then I think the experience would not be so great. We were lucky though and happy to recommend

Great tour with a Jeep into the park. Got to see a variety of animals in their natural habitat. A must see in this part of Sri Lanka. Additionally as a bonus and due to the fact that it was a day with heavy rain, we got to see a great and very entertaining river crossing by the different safari cars/drivers. It was like a mud rally with crazy action.

Our visit to Minneriya park was very exciting as me and my girl never seen an Elephant in the wild. We thought we could see 10-15 elephants. But instead we witnessed Elephant gatherings of more than 200 in a herd! Can you believe friends. Andrea counted 197 near the main lake area. The elephants were the center of attraction in the safari, but you could witness warthogs large amount of birds and buffaloes. If you are a elephant seeker, it's the best place in Sri Lanka. A safari tour will cost around $ 40/- including entrance and safari jeep. You can share the jeep with nearly 5 fellow travelers and reduce the cost as well.

Lots of elephants and bird life. Get your driver to take you away from the large number of safari jeeps and you will have a lovely time Saw lots of different eagles all fishing and of course the large herds of elephants and water buffalo This safari will be as good as your driver makes it for you !

this is one of the best places in srilanka to see tha wild eliphants,sambar deer,water buffalo,wild cats and crocodiles.its possible to see large number of elephants hear. the best time to observe elephant herds is from 3.00pm to 6.00pm.we had a wonderful experience in minneriya national park...

Our guide told us that we need to get into a jeep to access the park. We didn't expect that we will be sitting at the back of a bare roofed jeep without seatbelts onsite travelling at 70 miles per hour in a snaky road for over 30 minutes to reach the park itself. When accessed the park we had to drive for another 40 minutes in this busy track with jeeps overtaking each other, at first we were getting bored because there was just the occasional monkey here and there, an owl sitting up a tree in distance, lots of peacocks ..... but when we reached the elephant, it was worth the journey (if you are an elephant lover, this is a treat). I'm just amazed at the majestic sight of elephants, so to me it was worth it. My husband doesn't agree. After taking selfies from the back of the jeep, it was time for the dreaded jeep drive back to our car. Another hour or so to get back with my heart in my mouth at the back of the roofless, seatbeltless racing jeep. We survived the journey to write this review ;-)

"The Gathering" is when the elephants come together and hang out, for lack of a better word.  Coming to Minneriya NP was a last minute decision and are we ever glad we did. You have to ride in your jeep about 1/2 hour to get to the ancient reservoir where the elephants are.  But once you are there (with many other jeeps) you will see up to 300 elephants, or so we were told.  We saw two groups of about 30 elephants each.  And it's like weren't even there.  Of course, they are used to the jeeps, so they just go about their business.  We saw a very young one, about a week old.  They were blowing their horns and wallowing in the water, along side water buffalo.  Oh, what an experience, son't miss it!

My girlfriend and I have done a private safari in this NP. We paid 95$ for about 3 hours, 60 minutes of which we were just driving to and from the park entrance from Habarana. The roads were in such a bad condition that it really hampered the possibility of enjoying the drive. Furthermore our guide could hardly speak any english and the car was neither very comfortable nor could you fasten the seatbelts. The view to the front is completely blocked by the chassis of the car. The wordt part of the safari was that while beinh on the spot with the most elephants to see, I counted 86(!) other safari cars on the hunt for photos, which made our experience worse. It might be partly due to the fact that we're spoilt from our south african safaris, but we were not content over all and would not recommend it. Besides, it was way overpriced for Sri Lanka.

Friends of ours visited the park in the dry season so they saw huge herds of elephants. When we went, there was a small herd of about 25 elephants of all ages including  about half a dozen babies. Our driver was able to park very close, about 10 metres from the elephants and we stopped there in the quiet...only a few jeeps were there...to observe. The elephants went in the water and played, they chased each other, they sprayed water at each other, the babies ran around and at one point they all began to feed. It was very quiet, with no sound except the ripping up of the grass and munching noises. At this point they came closer and closer to us...only a few metres. A wonderful experience!
did safari lake breeze jeepes safari give good services more than 3hours spend national parck very good place

We were impressed by the great numbers of elephants, at several spots throughout the park.  It's easy to spot them on the plain fields (it's not a very bushy park) on their way to and from the water holes.  Many species of birds to be seen as well.  We didn't regret doing this jeep safari, despite the many other safari vehicles around at the same time (they all seem to enter the park around the same time between 14.30 - 15.00 h, and leave the park towards 18.00 h).  It wasn't too bad, though, not nearly as bad as in the Yala National Park (see separate review) which park should be avoided at all costs!!  Here in Minneriya we were at least not completely fumigated by the many diesel Jeeps.

Probably the best 10k rupees we've ever spent.  We saw large numbers of elephants at close quarters, water buffalo, a crocodile and wading birds and birds of prey too numerous to mention, all in the most beautiful and natural of settings.  We managed to see all this before the afternoon crowds arrived so there were only a handful of vehicles accompanying us on our safari.  Our guide was polite, enthusiastic and knowledgeable and had keen eyes.  More time to sit and observe might have improved our two hour experience though. Our driver on the other hand put his vehicle through its paces and gave us the bumpiest of bumpy rides.   He was also in a hurry to return, presumably to pick up his next fare. He then became awkward over his tip or in his case, lack of one! So get the right driver, take your time and you should have an unforgettable experience.
First time for us seeing Asian Elephants in the wild. The vehicles were designed for viewing. The road leading in and out was very long and bumpy.

We did an afternoon jeep safari as part of a Sri Lankan coach tour. As such we didn't have to take a chance on our guide/driver as we would if independent. Our driver was sharp-eyed and knowledgeable, spotting and identifying birds at a distance and stopping to let us take photos. It seemed that other jeeps were just driving as quickly as possible to the "hot" elephant spots. You do have to be prepared for a bumpy ride but being close up to elephant families is special and worth the discomfort. If you are interested in birds, look out for Indian Rollers, Painted Storks, Grey Headed Fish Eagles and Little Green Bee-Eaters. We did a similar jeep tour of Yala NP later in the tour and much preferred Minneriya (see separate review).

We booked this at the last minute and didn't know what to expect. There was a fair amount of jeep driving including at 60KPH++ without seat belts. It was quite expensive but you certainly get to see elephants - loads of them, and you can often get very close. Only problem as others have said, is if there were 100s of elephants there were probably 100s of landrovers too! They have to stop one person per vehicle as the number was crazy. So it is worth doing - just!
Visited whilst touring, saw so many elephants , what an experience in the jeeps too, we had a great driver who stopped to allow us to take photos and pointed out wildlife

Whilst wanting to see elephants our interest in wildlife is much greater. A real shame that our guide and driver couldn‚Äôt identify many of the bird species, got many wrong from our limited knowledge and didn‚Äôt have a pair of binoculars between them. And seeing 20 jeeps around a few elephant is very sad. National Parks need to learn from East Africa

Despite what the guide books are saying, you should go in the afternoon which is the best moment to see the elephants near the Lacs. We went at 6am and got lucky through the end to see 10 of them. However we saw lot of birds and other animals

A great park for a half day game drive - a beautiful place and plenty of elephants. We saw about 50 or so, along with buffalo, numerous birds and a HUGE water monitor. This thing was like a kimono dragon, easily 5-6 feet long. Well worth a visit.

Wow what an amazing experience.  We were lucky enough to have a very experienced ranger in the jeep with us and he took us to some of the quieter areas where we could see the elephants close up with less other jeeps around.  We saw so many females, babies and even some males in the distance.  We also saw some interesting birds and a few crocodiles.  Definitely worth a visit.

We chose to come here over Yala national park as we heard Yala was quite crowded. We chose to go with Lake Breeze Guest house for our jeep and he knew a great local guide. We were able to see herds of elephants as well as lots of birds and other animals.
We were lucky to see many elephants close by. Our guide Warner was very informative. The animals have 200000 acres to roam. Did spot quite a few birds. The four wheel drive experience was also fun!

Visited with a guide/ safari jeep, and a promise that we would see lots of elephants. Lost count after 100- all different family groups, some large, some just 3 or 4. The jeeps drive and park close enough for great viewing and photos. Drivers respectful of the animals, and move on if the elephants seem bothered by their presence. Also saw lots of birds including Eagles nesting, pelicans, kingfisher and heron.

A good place to visit to see the elephants but beware of the park guides who can choose any vehicle to get in, normally the ones who they think they can get the best tips from and your driver has to do as they tell him.

I would definitely recommend this national park for anyone new to Sri Lankan wildlife and is hoping to see some elephants. You are likely to see lots of them, and at close quarters. The natural landscape is lovely and a good experience for travelers of all ages who want to get off main roads and see something of the natural environment.Take sun protection and water.

You have to pay both entrance fee to the park and the hire of a jeep so not cheap, ( what‚Äôs new) did enjoy this trip albeit very dusty and you get thrown about a lot.  Saw quite a few herds  of elephants, some of the young were suckling their mother. You can get up quite close although obviously you can‚Äôt leave the jeep. Also water buffalo and we were lucky enough to see an eagle.  Can you class this as a safari? I‚Äôll leave it up to you

Not only did I see many elephants, grazing, showering and playing in the lake, I also very much enjoyed the ride in the jungle. It felt very much like being in an unspoilt natural environment. I took an afternoon safari, which was relaxed and not too busy, with not too many jeeps. Make sure you check your allocated car for comfort and maintenance before you hand out your money.

We enjoyed our afternoon but a safari it wasn't. It felt more like a wildlife park/zoo. There were way too many jeeps, completely surrounding the elephants, I felt sorry for them. The park needs to limit the number of jeeps or regulate it a bit better. As other people have said it is very bumpy and dusty - ladies wear a sports bra if you can! We were lucky to see some golden jackals and the bird life was fantastic.
We had a fantastic experience in our open top jeep. It was great sunny conditions and arrived at 3:30pm which was good timing to see the wildlife grazing.
Our local driver/guide took us here to experience elephants, buffalo and other wildlife in this beautiful conservation park. Highly recommended as you go in small groups.

I had to select the kind of trip as "Family with teenagers", however I visited this National Park with my parents (I am 27 years; no longer a teenager). Needless to say, you can visit this park withs small children and teenagers as well. My images do not do it justice; my iphone broke before the trip but I could save one!

So many elephants, our guide advised there were up to 300 in the herd. This was very well organised, although very popular so literally hundreds of tourists in 50+ vehicles, which does detract a little. Otherwise really enjoyed the 1/2 day trip. Note: Don't wear good clothes, we got a little dirty from mud kicked up when 4-wheel drive went through a muddy patch, all good fun.

We went with 7 adults and 1toddler. Hired a open Jeep . The vehicle cost was LKR 3000 for approximately 2 hours and we separately purchased entrance tickets. The ride was superb on bumpy roads we saw herds of elephants, foxes , Eagles and many birds. An officer from the wild life department accompanied us and gave us loads of information on the park. Only advice is if you are trancelike with young children, keep them in the middle and hold them tightly as the ride is bumpy and since it goes even between herd of elephants in case the driver has to speed during an emergency.

As we visited during the Christmas period, there were a lot of jeeps! It felt rather invasive of these animals home. Thankfully for the animals, the jeeps stayed a respectful distance. The driver explained that many of the animals were not coming out, due to the high volume of traffic. We were able to see several elephants, some birds and that was it. The nature itself was beautiful, so it was a pleasure to drive around. From what I understand, other parks have more variety of animals.

Multiple elephant sightings are practically guaranteed here. Although there are huge numbers of jeeps in the park, especially during afternoon/sundown, the drivers appear to be less cowboyish in attitude and more sensible than their Yala counterparts. A vehicle in good shape and a skilled driver took us across muddy river beds to reach areas of prime elephant viewing. Apart from these pachyderms, there are buffalo and birds (notably peacock) and the drive through the bush is itself quite pleasant. Headgear and sun-screen are musts!

We choose to take the jeep safari. It was well worth it. We saw three different herds of elephant, so very close feeding from the grass and also be able to see how the young ones are copping. Really recommend this visit.
I was surprised by the amount of elephants. It was so nice to see all the elephants from so close by. The Jeep tour was amazing and I would definitely recommend it.

Our guide had arranged a jeep 10km away from the park. It is a bumpy ride sitting on bench seats so not for those with bad backs. Part of the trail is through woodland then grass land areas. We saw three large herds of elephants quite close to as well as cows, a crocodile and quite a few birds. However is was very hot with no shade in our jeep.
Pick the right time so,it's not too busy and this is a wonderful place to see literally hundreds of wild elephants
That place amazing . You can see the reality of elephants life.from the tamarind resort 15 minutes by jeep . I can recommend to you this place highly..!!!

Group: 26 people of all ages from babies to seniors.. in 4 cars Price: 45$ for adult , half for children 6-12 and less than 6 free of charge + 1000R tips per car Recommended; highly recommended, amazing experience. Duration: 2 to 3 hours Animals: birds and elephants , elephants and elephants, you are up close to this beautiful animal in natural surroundings Experience: we loved it Weather was amazing Cars in. Very good condition Not crowded at all Got to see : mother& baby elephant ,many Times we saw a very big herd of elephants and we Could get very close to them The view and the area is so beautiful that you enjoy the ride even in the parts that you are not spotting the animals Notes: we went to Yala as well,we all preferd  Minneriya and found Yala over rated

This was our first time in this park. I have to say whilst I highly enjoyed the experience. To see the elephants in the wild was amazing. Our tour guide was very informative regarding the elephants also. I did feel some of the drivers got on and some of them were lose cannons. One driver over took us when we were heading back and nearly caused an accident. Some very dangerous driving this even compared to Sri Lankan driving as a whole. Well worth going to. One of the highlights for us during our trip to Sri Lanka

We took a jeep safari through Minneriya and really enjoyed it. However, our driver didn‚Äôt risk getting across the riverbed as lots of jeeps were getting stuck in the mud - this curtailed the experience a little. We did see many elephants roaming in the wild and the bird-life is also prolific. There are a lot of jeeps on the trails which can make it somewhat congested, however, I‚Äôd still recommend a visit. Udawalawe was actually our preferred safari and we hope to visit Yala in the future.

Visited here on a country your with my wife. Our guide had told us about the number of elephant that we might see, but I was a but scheptical but i should not have been! We went in a jeep and after about half an hour found ourselves at the side of a huge lake with around 200 elephant in front of us. What I will say is that it is very popular - there were several dozen other jeeps there too, but to be honest they all seemed to behave pretty sensibly and didnt get to close to the elephants. For their part they seem pretty oblivious to our presence and happily ate and played like we werent there. A fab experience and real highlight of our trip.
Bumpy ride. We must have had the oldest jeep. We saw many groups of elephants, about 60 in total. Amazing experience. Brilliant driver and guide. Highly recommended.
We thoroughly enjoyed our safari. The park is very beautiful. We were able to see an abundance of elephants. It was just amazing for us to see the elephants so close up. An unforgettable experience.

OK. So you've probably got big expectations of this park. It definitely has lots of elephants, particularly late August and September when the famous 'Gathering' takes place. It is probably almost certain that you'll see elephants any time of the year. But here's a reality check for you: the Jeep 'safari' that you've got in mind almost certainly will involve your Jeep and around twenty or thirty others that all jostle for position as soon as an unfortunate elephant is sighted. We're talking here of revving engines, other jeeps parking between you and the elephant so you can't see it.  You're going to be one of maybe 100 gawking tourists. We were actually caught in a traffic jam in the park! Horrible! This is unsustainable tourism. The Jeep drivers are not quite cowboys but close to it. There is no time or room for contemplating the wonders of nature in silence because all you'll here are revving engines. You might as well go to a zoo. We were extremely disappointed by our experience. All I can advise is to lower your expectations to rock bottom  - or simply don't go. It isn't what you might think it is.

We visited the park on a short 3/4 he safari trip. We saw lots of interesting birds. The highlight was the elephants. There were around 150 that we saw in total and it was amazing to see them in the wild. They are magnificent. Our driver was good too. Definitely worth a trip if you haven‚Äôt seen elephants in the wild before.
We been few times to Minneriya, Always guaranteed to see elephant if you go right time of the day. Be aware of the safari truck mafia

Had a lovely tour   Went around 3pm  saw one water buffalo and then lots of elephants Bumpy roads. Lots of dust and dirt which is understandable you are in nature and the paths/road is dirt because your in the elephants natural habitat

If you want to watch people on safari get too close to the poor wildlife then this is the place to go! There is no quota on jeeps and the result is disgusting. For some reason I can‚Äôt access the photos through the trip advisor app otherwise I would post them

I wouldn't classify this as a real safari, it was just an elephant viewing area that was jam packed with jeeps all trying to get a close up with the elephants. I was expecting to see some water buffalo or deer or pigs but it was only elephants and birds. Seeing the herd of elephants was neat but I got bored after 3 hours of it with nothing new to see. I think that for the price it is not worth it.

Excellent location to view elephants in their natural habitat.  We saw around 75 of them as well as numerous tropical birds.  Recommend going before the busy 3-6pm window as the park fills up with safari jeeps late in the afternoon.

My run with safaris has never been great, with barely an animal or 2 in sight. But Minneriya was a sight to behold! You hire a jeep (try to make advance bookings if you are going there on a weekend or national holiday because they tend to book out really fast) that takes you right into the national park near a lake where elephants of all sizes congregate in hoards! We went in the afternoon slot and saw tons of them - any photographer‚Äôs dream
A wonderful experience- while the guide couldn't guarantee we would see any elephants at all, we say 2 huge heards! It was a magical experience and would highly recommend.

Minneriya wasn't on our original itinerary, as we focus more on seeing the archaeological and religious sites. However, we found a gap in our schedule, and our excellent guide from Sri Lanka Personal Drivers set up a safari for us in a private 2 seat Jeep. We went around 1:30 in the afternoon, and it ended up being the perfect time (on the way out, we saw dozens of jeeps coming in, while we were the only one heading out). This also meant we had a five minute line for tickets, whereas the day before apparently had been an hour+. The first 20 minutes inside the park is just getting to the location, so you don't see much. But once it opens up, it was astonishing. We saw 3 distinct groups of elephants, each numbering 40-50. At times we were mere feet away. From not on the itinerary, it became easily one of our top experiences in Sri Lanka. Be aware that the elephants do tend to move around, so ensure you get word on whether they are more located at Kaudulla or Minneriya during your visit. We overheard other folks over dinner the night before saying they only saw a dozen or so Elephants at Kaudulla.

This was a fun few hours in a ‚ÄòSafari Jeep‚Äô getting up close to the elephants. We got some great pictures and our driver did his best to get us really near to the elephants, as did all of the other drivers. At times it felt more like being part of a herd of jeeps watching a much smaller herd of elephants. There wasn‚Äôt much else in the way of wildlife to see other than some interesting bird species, so overall definitely worth a visit to see lots birds and elephants but not what I would consider a true safari experience.
What an amazing experience, travelling through the jungle in a Jeep. We got too see peakcocks, pelicans, other birds and elephants. Great place to take photos and create memories.

Took a risk and went in the morning when the elephants could have been less visible. For the first hour we didn‚Äôt see any other jeeps in the park.  Early on saw deer, buffalo and peacocks. Eagles, storks, cranes as well. Finally saw the herd of elephants. We‚Äôre about 30 or so by the water including a few young ones. Kept a respectable distance away. Spent 20mins watching them before the next Jeep bumped along. Magical. A single male was also visible about 1km away. We drove around to see him a bit closer and then came across another 10 elephants moving through the scrub later. Finally a crocodile on the track that moved quickly into the water and some some wild monkeys sealed it for us. One of the highlights of our Sri Lankan trip.

Visit in the early morning to see the park waking up.  Plenty of Elephants for the jumbo watchers, and much easier to see and observe than other parks.  A large variety of birds and other wildlife too, and somehow the sanctuary seems much more relaxed.  The Minneriya tank is a definite plus, with the migratory birds found in large numbers in and around the water.  The trackers and guides are helpful too, and quite knowledgeable about the trees and herbs unique to Minneriya.
We had a great guide gave us enough time to capture the natural beauty of minneriya national park. We had a great time seeing elephants, local birds, Sri Lankan peakok & some monkeys üòä
Well worth doing - book a jeep and driver keep eyes peeled an you will see lots of wildlife and really large families of elephant.

Highly recommend visiting here, it is such an adventure! We visited mid November and were lucky to see over 50 elephants, an eagle and lots of different species of birds. There are a lot of bugs so be prepared to get bitten if they like you!

Was such a great park. Saw countless elephants, all in different places. The drivers help each other out which is nice, so if there‚Äôs been a sighting you don‚Äôt miss out. Saw so much more than elephants too - monkeys, buffalo, bee eaters, monitor lizards, parrots, giant squirrels, countless birds! Get feedback from your guide which the best Park is at the time of your visit, I‚Äôm really glad we chose this one!
We were very lucky to see so many elephants and different varieties of birds. There are a few jeeps but on our visit they kept a very respectful distance. Delightful experience

Headed into the park, all the drivers know where the elephants are, we restrained ourselves and saw monitor, storks, pelicans, egrets and a hawk before finding our own private spot to watch the herd of approximately 30 go about their daily ritual of feeding, drinking and the juveniles playing - testing their strength, particularly hysterical pushing themselves up and down the canals. Other vans joined as from time to time, particularly when the elephants came close. But we stayed and could hear them eating, communicating when the other vans moved on after a couple of pictures. 1000 elephant pictures to sort through!

If you like to watch elephants this is the place to visit. The best period of the year to visit is from July to October when the water around the area start to dry up. If you are lucky you can see 100+ numbers in a heard during that time. If you are going to visit this park and hire a safari jeep get a 4X4 and fix the price and minimum safari time of at least 2hrs. As it was the kids first visit to this park managed to show them around +/- 50 elephants including 3 young tuskers
345 jeeps for a day.80% are tourists .but they just have one ticket counter.we cant find the staff .they dont have any uniform .staff at the tickets checking counter are just like a wild animals .
To see the wild elephant this is the perfect place. All we saw were elephants, many of them and babies which I had not seen before. I recommend this attraction either early morning or early evening

Can't recommend this more highly.  Plenty of birds, elephants and deer to see - great landscape and plants as well. Downsides are the number of jeeps on the clear plains and getting bogged/helping others that got bogged.  Best to ensure your vehicle is a jeep, Toyota or Mitsubishi - not a Mahindra.  Also best to ask your guides to take the road where there are less other vehicles - our first two hours were by ourselves, completely, and it was excellent.  Was a little less impressive when we could see a 100 jeeps cramming in near the elephants on the open plains.
Despite the many jeeps, there are lots of elephants, deer and wart hogs. The birds are amazing - the wild peacocks are a trip.

We visited mid november and I actually had no idea what to expect. I'd read nothing before we arrived and I had in mind that it was a little like going on safari in that I may see one or two elephants. In fact, the first elephant appears in the trees and I already thought that was wonderful. We turned around the corner and there, i front of us were around 60 elephants. An utter delight to see. Our guide seemed quite savvy and when everyone else was getting closer and moving in one direction, he shot off in another and round the corner, we then saw around 200 elephants.... Just amazing. Such beautiful intelligent creatures. We watched families, babies, older and younger playing. We saw dynamics between different elehphants. We saw them eating and when some moved to the water hole, we saw them drinking too. I notice that some of the reviews say that they only saw a couple. There could be hundreds, as we saw, but they could be on another part of the park as they do like to walk and wander. My advice would be to do your research on the guides. Ours was certainly in contact with others to find where they were. Ours came through our Sri Lankan guide via Aitken  Spence.

We went there mainly to get a closer look at a large group of wild elephants (generally there should be 200+ elephants). But sadly, there was like 10 elephants in different isolated locations and we were not able to get close to them. (though we spotted a deer and a few birds). Because of the rain, the elephants were not required to come to the lake for grass or water. And the mud made the jeeps stuck preventing going to further areas. According to the driver, the best period to spot elephants is April to August. And we should get into the park around 2.30 pm. And most of the safari jeeps are 2WDs. Try to find yourself a 4WD if it‚Äôs rainy season. We went to kaudulla national park on the following day, because we really wanted to get closer look at the elephants. And there we found about 60-70 elephants. The cost for minneriya was : Rs. 3000 + charges for tickets The cost for kawdulla was : Rs. 4000  + charges for tickets

This park has to be one of the best option in Sri Lanka to see a lot of wild elephants. We atleast encountered a hundred of elephants with a baby elephant which was around 7 days old according to the guide. A must visit when in Habarana.
Incredible number of elephants. Saw hundreds including babies. Fantastic opportunity to get up close. Also lots of birds and few buffalo, but this is all about the elephants.

We spent a few hours driving around the park just before sunset one evening. We saw in excess of 100 elephants in separate groups, some came within a few feet of our jeep! We also saw eagles, peacocks and many other birds.  Having seen captive elephants in Thailand this was a treat and very special.

i just loved this park. I cannot yet decide whether this or Wilpattu is my favorite in Sri Lanka, among the parks I have visited so far, but it is definitely the number one destination if you love elephants. if you do not, you will fall in love with them after a visit in Minneriya. It is impossible to stay indifferent to these magnificent creatures. You can meet as many as 300 elephants at the same time up close, and the location is great too: wide spaces, huge lake, so plenty of birds around as well. It will not take more than 4 hours, but, wow, what a great time you will have there. Guaranteed... i also suggest that you book it  when you arrive, not online. ask for the advice of locals, they know better, or the place where you are staying (just note 4-5 star hotels will charge much more than the direct prices).

A must-do!  Our jeep driver was very good and we had it to ourselves so plenty of room to see everything clearly.  Saw lots of elephants including two large herds with tiny babies!   They were very entertaining.  We got caught in torrential rain and lightening which went on for most of our safari but it just made the elephants more active and playful as they were loving the rain!  An amazing experience.

If all you want to see are Elephants this is your best shot. The vast open spaces makes going up to the herds really easy. It isn't a waiting game like Yala or Wilpattu. Theyr'e just out there in the open usually.

Our elephant safari was booked at one of the many roadside vendors but ours came recommended by our trusty driver. The Mahindra Bolero 4x4 picked us up from our hotel and took us to the Minneriya National Park where our guide was very quickly pointing out exotic wildlife to us‚Ä¶ kingfishers, Peacocks, Crocodiles, water buffalo, monkeys and of course the Elephants. The Elephants were the highlight of the tour, initially seeing a solitary bull elephant and then shortly thereafter seeing a herd of around 70 elephants of all ages travelling down to the waters edge of the Minneriya reservoir. After taking hundreds of photos of this magnificent herd in brilliant light conditions we moved to find a smaller family group of 5 elephants and then later a mother large herd of around 60+ elephants. It was an absolutely awe inspiring sight seeing these magnificent creatures up close in the wild like this. Be aware though that yours is not the only jeep on the safari‚Ä¶ at one point the number of 4x4s exceeded the number of elephants! The drivers are all aware of the issues this poses and do their best to avoid driving into one another shots
It was lovely to see two herds of wild elephants and a couple of lone bulls. It was an interesting experience and getting stuck in the mud and having to be towed out was a first!

The Park is covers a huge area and the only way to access the park is by way of Jeep which can be hired to drive you through the park. It is too hot and humid to walk and I could see that there were no hikers on foot. I believe that the Park authorities do not permit anyone to go in without a guide or on foot.

Well we only saw two elephant families, so all together about 10 elephants. Then there was small birds and buffalo's. I was keen on seeing herds of elephants, but our guide said that this is not the time.

Minnerya Wildlife Park where you can see at close range large herds of wild elephants and water buffaloes gathering and feeding openly and enjoying themselves free in nature. Wonderful sight. Kids and family will love it. Where else can you see such large herds simply gathering in such free and easy manner openly relaxing in natural environments. Worth every cent. Please do not miss this place if you are visiting Sri Lanka. Be awed by the experience

Minnerya and Kadulla National Park is vast and beautiful. So many varieties of birds. Excellent place to see large herds of wild elephants and water buffaloes gathering and feeding openly and enjoying themselves free and at peace with nature. Astounding experience just to enjoy these animals close. A truly must see experience for the entire family especially kids who will have fun and learn the beauty of these wild herds GATHERINGS. Highly recommended worth every cent. Please do not miss this wonderful educational family experience
If you want to see elephants this is the place to visit. However the gatherings are seasonal (May to September as I can remember). The hotels nearby will arrange visits for you. A must visit !

Five of us took a safari here which involves being driven through the park in an open FWD accompanied by a guide. October is the shoulder season, before the monsoon which means there are still plenty of elephants to see in the park but not the big crowds of the high season. It is a beautiful park.  After a 30 minute drive through the jungle/forest and spotting a minute lizard, chameleon, monkeys and several bird species, the park opens up to a huge plain which in the wet is mostly a lake.  In the dry the lake is smaller but still significant. Apparently 300- 400 elephants come down to the lake-side at the height of dry season in August to drink.  We saw a herd of about 30 with many babies, and two other smaller beards plus a few bulls, one up close. We were able to get fairly close to the large heard and there were at most three or four other vehicles, so everyone had a chance to see.  The baby elephants frolicked and fed making for great photos and video. There was also a large herd of water buffaloes and many pea cocks and hens.  Also some interesting bird life. The ride is a little rough especially if you stand rather than sit which we did for the view. But this would only be a problem for the very frail.  Our guide was very helpful and knowledgeable.  About $US 30 a head for a bit over two hours is great value.

We went there wwith an agency from sigiriya, hinestly I think it's better to go on place and to get a jeep directly at the entree, there are a lot and they waiting for people... prices should be better. We had luck, we've seen soooo many elephnats, also crocodiles, chameleones, differnets kind of birds, bees, etc... honestly if you ever been in this corner of the world, nothing amazing for animals excepting elephants, and just for that... it woth it! You have to check before where they are as they moving during the year (3 differents park). If you have a guide he could do this for you. If you're doing the same as us, you have to know that you can negociat the prices, we had 2500 roupias less on the price as we show the routard guide telling it should be cheaper...

Was a fantastic experience visiting the national park and seeing elephants in their natural habitat! After visiting an elephant sanctuary in Thailand and hearing the horrible things done to elephants to 'domesticate' them, I couldn't think of any worse than seeing a show or riding an elephant therefore it was amazing to be able to see them, how they should be, in the wild! We did also see monkeys, a crocodile and some bird life too but we saw so many families of elephants! My one criticism would be that their doesn't seem to be a limit on the amount of jeeps let into the national park at any one time and some get very close to the animals to the point of being intrusive but otherwise I would highly recommend a trip to this park.

The scenery itself is stunning, vast open plains with a beautiful lake. If you don't mind the sun (3-4 hours drive in open fields) go open-top. Elephants are everywhere in herds. There are the occasional crocodiles and monkeys, if you are lucky leopard too.

This trip was amazing. We were so well looked after. We had our own jeep and did no0t feel rushed throughout the trip but we able to enjoy the tour. We saw so many elephants. I'm talking maybe 50 or so. In their natural habitat. It was amazing to watch them behaving naturally. There are also numerous birds and other wildlife to see. Definitely make this part of your holiday!

We enjoyed a 4 hour safari in an open jeep.  Bumpy road- but great fun. The jolts were more than compensated for by the sheer magic of seeing 6-8 herds of wild elephants (about 160+).  They ranged in size from babies to 40-50 year old adults. Other animals were storks, Ibis, Egrets, Eagle, Iguano, buffalo, cattle & lots of birds.  Fantastic!

The sole purpose of my trip to Sri Lanka was to see the annual elephant "GATHERING" that takes place in this park.  It happens because of the dry weather and the ellies come here for water and green grass.  WELL....this year Mother Nature decided to give them plenty of water so there was no drought and therefore NO GATHERING>>>!!!  Oh well, I knew in advance that nature does what nature wants to do and not what tourists want it to do.  Nevertheless, I had some fine ellie viewing anyway.  Not huge herds as I had hoped, but good stuff anyway.  I had some very good photo ops with the ellies and came away happy.

Had been to this Park while on tour in Srilanka. The Entrance with the Jeep type at the gate and the entire worthiness of it doesnot go hand in hand. The entrance is exhorbitantly costly, advisable if a bargain is striked with the Jeep driver of the park else it is a complete Drain on ones pocket and timein this Park. One has to be prepared to get a very sad upkeep of the park as if deteriorated by insiders of its greens and woods, as well as there is no such proper fauna and flora for the animals to be part of this park. this view is as compared to one in tour in south africa or Kenya. The entire park area is sadistically barren, hardly any Animals to be spotted and one gets completely drenched out in the scorching sun with no beautiful aura of the entire park as such. pleas emake sure to cancel out this unadvisable, uneconomical and time wasting trip that has no value when the management itself has no interest in the upkeep of Animals and its flora and Fauna  compared the country being full of green flora and fauna else where in wild. The ride itself is very dangerous as drivers are not of that calibre or disheartened at their Jobs. Am apologising for this negative review to help many before investing time into this journey. worthy is to visit Africa if for animals in wild and in variety.

A great safari. We saw lots of elephants. My only negative is that the National Park allows so many jeeps into the one zone. There doesn't seem to be any control over the way some jeeps are driven when trying to get close to the elephants.

Arranged for a 6 am jeep safari. Had a great guide from the national park service who pointed out all the interesting birds and had the driver stop so we could take photos. Saw two male elephants up close. He said the morning safari allows you to see more wild life and the afternoon safari departing at 2:30 brings you to The Gathering which has more elephants. We thought this was a spectacular experience. Departs at 6 am and returns at 8:30. Take a look at the museum too.

Wonderful experience spending time with the elephants in their own back yard. Far too many Jeeps attending at once and some getting too close. I'm pleased to say that ours kept its distance. The elephants did on occasion react to those who were infringing a little too much on their personal space.

The elephant safari here really is as good as it gets, we saw around 100 elephant who passed us within a few meters of the Jeep. Guides were experienced and very friendly. During the 3 hour safari We also viewed water buffalo, monkeys and various birds but it's the elephant experience that we will remember.
We had an amazing time visiting Minneriya National Park and saw over a hundred elephants. Definitely recommend !

Had a lovely experience, we saw a number of asian elephants close up and spent a good amount of time with them. The visit was not part of our itinerary booked through Southall Travel, it was an "extra" arranged with our driver.  We paid 10 thousand for the vehicle plus park entrance fees, as opposed to 5 thousand rupees paid by Simon B on his review dated 17th August. Hence the word of caution re: fees.

Safari jeep ride into Minneriya. I thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience and would recommend to everyone visiting this area. Ok, it felt a little bit like a UK safari park at times, following a set route and with lots of other jeeps around. We saw 2 elephants, 1 up close and probably only 20 feet away. A memorable experience.

We went on a safari to catch a glimpse of elephants in the wild. With a good driver and 4x4 vehicle, you will be able to spot a couple of herds and get a lesson on the lifestyle of these magnificent animals. The landscape is African-like, and the Jeep ride loads of fun. However, bring a hat, a good sunscreen and a pair of binoculars. You will, unfortunately, do as much people watching as animal watching, both being equally fascinating.

As a family of four we took a jeep with The Elephant Voyage from Habarana.  They were introduced by our driver and met us at the park gate for an afternoon visit (we were staying in Polonnaruwa).  Jeep cost 5000 rupees, park fees were separate. It was a dry overcast afternoon, we started shortly before 2pm and we saw one lone elephant and one group of elephants together with a selection of other wildlife.  I was a little disappointed but it was early in the season and our driver did his best by getting us to the right place at the right time.   The drive through the park was fun and me and our 13 year old enjoyed standing up and looking out/ducking tree branches as we went along.

This was a 2.5 hour safari where we booked the jeep in advance which saved us Rs2000 to just showing up. Our guide knew what he was doing and took us to a place without any other jeeps around. We saw a lovely group of elephants with some baby elephants - great experience. We then went to a place with more elephants, but I counted 50 jeeps and approx 45 elephants. Did not feel as nice as the first encounter. All in all, great experience with guaranteed elephant sightings, so good for kids..

Sad experience as we didn't get to see a single elephant in about 2.5 hrs spent here.  Our driver picked us up at 6 am from our hotel in Sigirya in jeep and drove us to Guadala national park whereas we had talked on Minneriya.  We rerouted for Minneriya as we had heard so much of it on tripadvisor.. However didn't get to see a single elephant. The jeep experience was little pricey though lots of fun especially for my little daughter.  I advice on checking with your agent first which park is best and at what point of time.

only to visit with a jeep tour; and their are too many of them. of course tourists want to see eliphants. but why are there many Jeeps with just to persons in the car instead of 6? why not small vans, so that more people can watch, with less vehicles. we saw that the eliphants were really disturbed, and even try to attack some jeeps And: in Sri Lanka you can see in a lot of places Eliphants, you don't need to go specially to Minneriya. the tour guides predict you will see 70 to 100 Eliphants take a bath, but because of all the Jeeps, the Eliphants couldn't reach the water and were waiting till 18.00 pm, when everyone needs to leave the park. we saw a few small groups of eliphants, all together maybe 40 eliphants. nice to see them in the wild and closeby, but we didn't feel really well about this visit. it disturbs the animals too much, park rangers try to handle this.

It's worth getting up early to meet your jeep at dawn and be in the park first thing in the morning.  It's cooler then and animals are up and roaming around before taking shelter from the heat later.  Elephant families with babies, birds soaring over the plain, mongoose scurrying home with breakfast tight in its teeth, herd of gaur heading back from the lake, fish eagles diving ...  The guides spot the animals long before you do, and patiently point them out until you spot them too.  Excellent trip.
